Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the 26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain. We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe. Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 3. Diverse, blue-chip customer base with longstanding, contractual relationships
Subsubsection Text: We supply over 1,000 customers across a range of resilient product categories and end markets. No single customer represented more than 8% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with our top 10 customers representing 32% of sales for the same period. Our customers include blue-chip, global food and consumer businesses including Abbott, Bonduelle, Danone, Nestle and Unilever, large national and regional food companies, as well as many smaller and independent fisheries and farmers. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers on average for over 25 years. We are the sole or main supplier for several of our top customers. We believe that the quality of our products, our track record of providing reliable supply proven over decades and the significant costs to customers involved in switching manufacturers creates customer stickiness. Before a manufacturing plant or line can begin manufacturing new can SKUs for a customer, its products typically must be qualified through a process that can take several months to over a year. In addition, can manufacturers may face downtime on their lines when running new SKUs, thereby impacting customers’ security and reliability of supply. Customers who decide to change manufacturers also typically lose the benefit of volume rebates from former suppliers and face uncertainty regarding the stability, reliability and quality of their new partners. Customers praise our technological know-how, understanding of their requirements and ability to produce and deliver large volumes of specialty food cans consistently on time and in full. Our customers incur high costs if their packaging is not delivered when required. As an example, tomatoes must be sealed in their packaging within six hours of being picked to ensure their freshness, often requiring our manufacturing facilities to ship dozens of truckloads of food cans per day in a continuous rotation to certain customer facilities during harvest season. We are recognized as an industry leader in product development and deliver solutions that offer greater consumer convenience and functionality in response to market demands. Can fillers require producers who can satisfy their branding, quality and safety needs. We believe we consistently satisfy these needs and enable our customers to differentiate their brands through packaging and address changing safety requirements ahead of time.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 4. Sustainability- and consumer-driven tailwinds benefit metal packaging
Subsubsection Text: Our metal packaging products are favorably positioned to benefit from the increase in demand for sustainable packaging given their infinitely recyclable nature. Greater environmental consciousness and strong sustainability trends are expected to support an increased preference for metal packaging over the long-term. End consumers increasingly view sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging. Food producers – our customers – are aggressively responding to this demand. For example, several major food conglomerates have announced that they aim to sell mostly recyclable or reusable materials by 2025. These trends are further reinforced by regulatory developments. For example, the EU circular economy plan adopted in 2020 has a clear focus on recyclable packaging, which is likely to put pressure on plastic in favor of other packaging materials. Metal packaging provides excellent options for the sustainability initiatives of companies and brands, since metal properties do not degrade during use or recycling. Consumers already recognize metal packaging as a highly recyclable substrate, evidenced by recycling rates of over 80% for steel and 75% for aluminum in Europe, and food brands increasingly want to position themselves as environmentally friendly. As a further sustainability benefit, metal packaging’s superior barrier properties make it ideal for food preservation, which reduces food waste. Metal packaging increases the accessibility of healthy foods in an economical manner and provides contamination protection, thereby reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses. Within the metal packaging industry, we are a European leader in sustainability awareness as a Co-Founder of the Metal Packaging Europe Association and an active participant in other major sustainability focused associations, which serve as conduits for sustainability reform at the regulatory and legislative level.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 5. Attractive financial profile with flexible cost structure and ability to generate consistent free cash flow
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track-record of robust free cash flow generation and cash conversion as a result of our flexible cost structure and resilient cash flows. We generated average annual free cash flow of $239 million and an average cash conversion rate of approximately 88% from 2018 to 2020. ----- Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and negotiated pass-through mechanisms, providing us with consistent historical cash flows and supporting our margins. We have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, over 97% of Titan Group’s pricing for 2021 was already agreed. We estimate that approximately 87% of our cost base is fully- or semi-variable, consisting mostly of material costs, labor costs, freight, energy, which represented 61%, 15%, 5% and 3%, respectively, of our total costs for the year ended December 31, 2020 in addition to other consumables. The semi-variable characteristics of our labor costs come from our ability to reduce our labor costs through the use of seasonal and temporary employees. Our variable cost structure allows us to quickly adapt our production capacity to harvest cycles, which can result in modest volume fluctuations from year to year. Our cash flow stability is bolstered by the non-cyclical end-markets we serve, our ability to pass-through raw material prices changes, our long-term customer relationships with contracted volumes, and customer stickiness. Our modest capital expenditure requirements and well-managed, disciplined approach to working capital further strengthen our free cash flow conversion. We believe our free cash flow profile will enable us to reduce leverage through debt repayment over time.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 6. Experienced management team supported by a best-in-class financial sponsor
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from a talented management team with deep roots in the business and decades of experience. Our management team has a strong track-record of value creation in the consumer packaging industry and has an average 30 years of service in the industry. Our management team has been involved in the preparation of our transition from being a part of Crown to operating as a stand-alone business, including the development of our stand-alone strategy. We have also moved to reinforce the team in its new existence as a stand-alone company by announcing the appointment of Tomás López as Chief Executive Officer. Mr López will bring experience and a track-record of success in managing Mivisa before it was acquired by Crown. See also “Management.” KPS Capital Partners (“KPS”) has a strong track-record of realising improvements in manufacturing companies and over two decades of constructive investing in highly complex corporate carve-outs on a global basis. KPS creates value for its investors by working constructively with talented management teams to make businesses better, and generates investment returns by structurally improving the strategic position, competitiveness and profitability of its portfolio companies, rather than primarily relying on financial leverage. KPS will support management and leverage its core operational improvement expertise. Furthermore, Crown will retain a 20% equity stake in the stand-alone company, validating its belief in the potential of the business and allow for a smooth transition of the business to an independent company.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: 1. According to leading global consulting firm 2. According to Management estimates We sell our products in more than 90 countries with France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany representing 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of our sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and other geographies making up the remaining 41% of sales in the same period. Sales to our top 10 customers represented just 32% of our total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers for an average of over 25 years. Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up ----- to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European tinplate packaging industry. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $303 million, $247 million and $267 million, respectively. Our net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were $2,297 million and $317 million, respectively, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. These amounts translate, for convenience purposes only, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, to net sales of €1,897 million, €1,910 million and €1,951 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of €256 million, €221 million and €234 million, respectively, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of €1,974 million and €272 million, respectively. Metal cans represent the best barrier material and provide a shelf life of over two years while still retaining the freshness of the food being packaged. In addition, metal food cans provide a host of other benefits to our customers, including i) allowing for fast filling speeds with limited loss, ii) having high strength and allowing for ease of handling and iii) being resistant to corrosion, thereby allowing for high-acid contents (e.g., tomatoes). These qualities make our products highly costeffective solutions for our customers and limit the threat of substitution from other substrates. ----- The stability of our end-markets is evidenced by their historical and forecast growth rates. According to a leading global consulting firm market growth for the packaging of shelf stable vegetables, culinary products, infant nutrition products and shelf stable fish in Europe have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2015 and 2020, and are expected to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2020 and 2024. Furthermore, between 2015 and 2020 the food can volumes sold in Iberia grew by a CAGR of 2% and in our other key markets of France, Italy, the UK and Germany food can volumes fluctuated by a CAGR of less than +/-1.5% over this period.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: 1. Longstanding European market leader and critical asset in the European food packaging supply chain
Subsubsection Text: We are the clear leader in the European market for food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. Sales of metal food cans and ends represented 85% of our total revenue in this period. We also believe that we hold the number one or number two market position in Europe across the other product categories we serve, namely metal closures, aerosol cans and promotional containers with market shares of approximately 28%, 12% and 24%, respectively, measured by volume for the year ended December 31, 2020. We have been in the European market for over 200 years and have a reputation with customers for providing the highest quality products and superior service. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Including intermediate precursor products, our manufacturing assets produce 500 million products per day on average. We have a well-established manufacturing presence with 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) across 17 countries enhancing access to customers, end markets, local demand and suppliers. We operate 34 food cans & ends manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period), five closures manufacturing facilities, three aerosol manufacturing facilities and three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities. We have a well-invested asset base supported by in-house research and development expertise. We believe the investment required to replicate our facility footprint, in addition to the know-how of operating canmaking assets that we developed over our history create high barriers to entry. The European market for food cans and ends is mature and highly consolidated with the top two players, ourselves and our primary competitor, holding a combined market share of over 65% based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. The third largest manufacturer has a market share of 3%. Other competitors consist of mostly regional or local manufacturers, who lack the ability to serve larger food customers at scale or are limited in their ability to serve customers across multiple geographies. The European food cans and ends market is relatively insulated from import competition given the high cost of shipping metal packaging long distances and the short lead times customers demand. Due to the significance of transportation costs in the food can industry, our regional production capabilities support expedient and cost-efficient transportation to local customers. Furthermore, there are high barriers to entry due to sizeable capital requirements needed to add capacity, rigorous qualification requirements demanded by customers, and heightened scrutiny with respect to safety requirements as a result of serving sensitive food end-markets. We hold a critical position in the European food packaging supply chain as the largest European manufacturer of metal food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel. Our business is the key link between tinplate steel, a commodity raw material that we purchase and convert to finished packaging for our large and fragmented, primarily European, customer base of food manufacturers. Can producers are the largest consumers of tinplate steel in Europe, with approximately 90% of tinplate steel in Europe being used in packaging, of which 40 to 50% is for food cans and 10 to 15% is for each of beverages, general line, aerosols and closures. Moreover, the market is largely stable with no significant shifts expected. We ----- are Europe’s largest buyer of tinplate, consuming approximately 20% of all tinplate production in Europe in 2020 according to Management estimates. Tinplate steel suppliers rely on us for a stable source of demand, and our position as the largest consumer of tinplate steel makes us a critical partner to all of the major suppliers of tinplate steel in the European market. Our over 1,000 customers rely on us as Europe’s largest supplier of food cans and ends. Because of our scale, we are often the only supplier that can serve high volume customers on a pan-European basis. Our customers depend on our supply to go to market and rely on our packaging to ensure their products reach store shelves. We provide their products with the benefit of a long shelf life that metal food cans offer. Our packaging is an important part of our customers’ brands, and we work closely with our customers to develop designs that ensure their products are attractive to end-consumers at points of sale.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: 2. Diverse, stable revenue mix with exposure to a range of non-cyclical, food-related end markets
Subsubsection Text: We sell essential food packaging products into a highly diverse mix of geographies, customers and end-markets, which supports revenue stability and resilience. Our products serve over 90 countries consisting of both sales into mature, developed countries and higher growth, developing countries. No single country represented more than 15% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with the largest contributors being France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany at 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Our product portfolio consists 95% of food packaging, which has historically experienced stable demand throughout economic cycles. We serve numerous food-related end-markets, including shelf-stable fruit and vegetables, shelf-stable fish, culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula, which represented 24%, 18%, 11%, 8% and 8% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers, such as population growth, eating at home trends, urbanization, and a growing global middle class, that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles, and not subject to significant innovation threats.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Business has numerous growth opportunities arising from favorable consumption trends, such as a greater focus on convenience, growth in single serve packaging, increasing premiumization and higher focus on sustainability. Operating as a stand-alone entity, we will have greater flexibility to pursue opportunities that were not previously considered or prioritized while integrated within the wider Crown business. In addition, we will have the benefit of a steady capital expenditure program ----- that is focused on our business, allowing us to pursue multi-year growth projects which we were unable to pursue under prior ownership. End-markets such as infant nutrition and wet petfood have volume growth opportunities at attractive margins that we believe we can capture by employing our capabilities and expertise developed in other end-markets. Our metal cans are well-positioned to benefit from these growth opportunities in light of their favorable barrier properties and the premium perception and convenience that our products offer. In addition, we are focused on growing our share and penetration in key emerging markets such as Eastern Europe and Africa, where our existing customers are establishing footprints that we can readily support with existing technologies and know-how.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Tinplate steel makes up for more than 80% of our raw materials spend and represented 48% of our cost of products sold in the year ended December 31, 2020. We believe our market position enables us to optimize sourcing and pricing for our tinplate steel purchases and provides further opportunities for margin expansion. While the Business under Crown’s ownership mainly focused on ensuring stability of supply and favorable working capital arrangements, as a stand-alone business we will have the opportunity to manage supply arrangements in support of better margins, including through utilizing a greater share of raw materials from low cost countries. We have developed optimization initiatives to realize the most favorable pricing with suppliers for the highest quality tinplate with the shortest supply chain lead times. There is potential for additional cost savings opportunities in the form of reduced spend on logistics, raw material specification complexity reductions, indirect cost savings and contract structure improvements. We believe there is an opportunity to purchase higher volume of fewer SKUs, and also consolidate production of precursor products into fewer facilities, thereby reducing the number of facilities receiving raw material shipments and to improve the structure of certain of our contracts. In addition, we believe there are opportunities to optimize indirect and other materials procurement through targeted sourcing initiatives. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, Titan Group already realized the benefit of improved procurement practices and commercial efforts, leading to expanding margins for this period.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We expect to realize further efficiencies by improving the asset utilization and productivity of our manufacturing footprint. We intend to employ targeted capital expenditures focused on modernizing the equipment used at several of our key facilities with a goal of increasing the capacity of those facilities and allowing more efficient and cost-effective production while reducing the number of facilities in our network. Our Business grew substantially following the acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, however, we did not fully integrate the Mivisa and legacy manufacturing footprints and did not achieve the margin targets or synergies forecast at the time. We believe that there are certain manufacturing function overlaps and duplications as a result of the acquisition and our organic growth. We intend to replicate the “hub and spoke” operating model, used successfully by Mivisa, whereby certain functions that can easily and cost-effectively be transported are completed at lower cost plants to improve and optimize asset utilization. For example, we believe that the manufacturing of ends and certain upstream functions such as metal processing and coating can be consolidated into facilities that specialize in production of those precursor products. Such products would then be transported to existing can finishing or assembly plants that are located close to our customers and have a lean operating footprint. This approach was successfully developed at Mivisa, which operated the largest ends production facility in the world in Murcia, Spain, producing more than 9 billion ends annually and serviced nearly its entire network using this plant and also serviced a significant export business of ends. We intend to replicate this model across the Group’s existing manufacturing footprint.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: 4. Commercial Excellence and Continuous Improvement Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: In addition to revenue improvement and market share capture, our strategy also has a strong focus on delivering further cost savings and unlocking further margin improvement potential. We plan to develop a continuous improvement culture and invest in training across the entire business. KPS and Management have conducted a comprehensive and granular review of our operating model. We believe that as a stand-alone business, we will be able to realize these cost savings and margin expansions based on KPS’ proven track record in realising improvements in manufacturing businesses. We have identified a number of commercial excellence and continuous improvement priorities, including (i) more focused deployment of capital expenditures, (ii) quality management in the form of manufacturing and operational excellence initiatives; (iii) maintenance and repair optimization, (iv) using a local sales force to improve engagement between our sales and operations teams and (v) a focus on customer service, innovation and responsiveness initiatives. As a stand-alone business focused on the manufacturing of food cans and ends, we will be more readily able to pursue these opportunities rather than having to compete with the other capital priorities of our former owner. ----- Our planned capital projects include investments focused on asset productivity, such as tooling upgrades to multi-die presses and high speed printing and coating lines capable of delivering up to 300% improvements in productivity. Our planned capital projects typically have a payback of approximately two to three years. We also believe there is an opportunity to improve the effectiveness of our commercial function by streamlining our financial reporting structure, providing greater visibility to our local sales teams and enabling them to optimize the margin profile of products they are selling. We believe our customers derive significant value from our product offering and we intend to capture additional margin for the superior service and capabilities that we offer.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Our strong cash flow generation has historically been utilized in support of broader goals within the larger Crown organization. We have a unique position in the European food supply chain as the largest manufacturer of food cans and ends in Europe and we believe that we are the largest buyer of tinplate steel in Europe. We believe that, despite our market position, our historic margins have lagged those of key competitors and our own potential as a result of the lack of focus on our business under our prior owners. Under Crown’s ownership, the business has mainly focused on volumes and cash generation to support Crown’s other businesses, which presents a significant opportunity for margin improvement. From 2017 to 2020, Titan Group represented approximately 20% of Crown’s sales but only 8% of its capital expenditures. As a stand-alone business, we aim to reorient the business towards growth and margin improvement. Capitalizing on the above strengths as a stand-alone business, we believe we have numerous levers to create additional value, grow volumes, improve profitability and generate cash flows.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a private company with limited liability (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands on April 1, 2021, for the purpose of facilitating the Transactions, having its corporate seat (statutaire zetel) in Amsterdam, the Netherlands and its registered office at Keizersgracht 555, 1017DR Amsterdam, the Netherlands. The Issuer is registered with the Dutch trade register under registration number 82416834.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: On April 8, 2021, Bidco and Crown entered into the Acquisition Agreement, pursuant to which Bidco will acquire the Titan Group conducting the Business. Through the Acquisition, KPS, or an affiliate thereof, will indirectly acquire 80% of the ownership interests in the Titan Group, with the remaining 20% being continued to be held by Crown (excluding ownership of Titan Group by Senior Management). The purchase price for the Acquisition of the Business will be €2.25 billion, subject to customary purchase price adjustments to reflect any changes in net debt, net working capital and cash in accordance with the Acquisition Agreement. The closing of the Acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions, including receipt of clearance from the EU competition authority and, pursuant to applicable laws, informing and/or consulting with the relevant employee representatives in France and the Netherlands. The longstop date for closing under the Acquisition Agreement is October 15, 2021. KPS, or an affiliate thereof, and Crown will, on or around the Completion Date, enter into a shareholders’ agreement, setting out Crown’s rights as a minority investor as well as a non-compete covenant undertaken by Crown based on the terms agreed by the parties in a shareholders’ agreement term sheet at signing. See “Related Party Transactions—Related Party _Transactions—Shareholders’ Agreement.”_ Crown or one or more of its subsidiaries, on the one hand, and Bidco or one or more of its subsidiaries, on the other hand, will each provide transition services to the other pursuant to the Transitional Services Agreement to be entered into by and between the Crown and Bidco at the closing of the Acquisition. See “Related Party Transactions—Related Party _Transactions—Transitional Services Agreement.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Acquisition will be financed as follows (collectively, the “Financing”): - the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby in an aggregate principal amount of €375.0 million; ----- - Bidco will enter into the Credit Facilities Agreement and borrow €1,175.0 million under the Term Loan B Facility; and - KPS, or an affiliate thereof, and Crown will, subject to variation through, among other things, customary completion accounts adjustments as set out in the Acquisition Agreement, make an equity contribution in an aggregate amount of €700 million. In connection with the Acquisition, on the Completion Date, a Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of up to €275.0 million will be made available to Bidco and certain of its subsidiaries for general corporate and working capital purposes. The Revolving Credit Facility is currently not expected to be drawn on the Completion Date. See “Capitalization.” In connection with the Acquisition, certain existing factoring and other similar arrangements of the Titan Group are envisioned to be rolled over. See “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements.” The net proceeds from the Financing will be used to: - fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition; - fund cash on Titan Group’s balance sheet; and - pay fees and expenses in connection with the Acquisition and the Financing, including the fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the closing of the Offering on the Issue Date, the Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account, to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. The Escrow Account will be in the name of the Issuer and will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not _completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the Notes.”_ The release of the Escrow Proceeds and the consummation of the Acquisition will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. If these conditions are not satisfied on the business day following the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but not including the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein). See “Risk _Factors—Risks related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the Notes.”_ In the event that the special mandatory redemption price payable upon a special mandatory redemption exceeds the Escrow Proceeds, the Sponsor will, pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter, be required to make an equity contribution to the Issuer to pay any funding shortfall to cover the accrued and unpaid interest, and Additional Amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes and any negative interest charged on the Escrow Account. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of _Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”_ Upon release of the proceeds from escrow, the proceeds of the Offering, together with the shareholder contributions and proceeds from the Credit Facilities Agreement as described above, will be used to finance the Acquisition and pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions as shown in the table above.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The Transactions consist of the following: - the consummation of the Financing; - the consummation of the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement; and - the payment of costs, fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing transactions, including the fees and expenses to be incurred in connection with the Transactions. For descriptions of our anticipated indebtedness following the Transactions, see “Description of Certain Financing _and Guarantee Arrangements” and “Capitalization.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Entities advised by affiliates of KPS indirectly hold 80% of the shareholding of the Issuer and control the Issuer. Crown owns the remaining 20%. Following the Acquisition, Titan Group will be indirectly wholly owned by the Issuer. KPS, through its affiliated management entities, is the manager of the KPS Special Situations Funds, a family of investment funds with over $12.8 billion of assets under management (as of March 31, 2021). For nearly three decades, the Partners of KPS have worked exclusively to realize significant capital appreciation by making controlling equity investments in manufacturing and industrial companies across a diverse array of industries, including basic materials, branded consumer ----- healthcare and luxury products, automotive parts, capital equipment and general manufacturing. KPS creates value for its investors by working constructively with talented management teams to make businesses better, and generates investment returns by structurally improving the strategic position, competitiveness and profitability of its portfolio companies, rather than primarily relying on financial leverage. The KPS Funds' portfolio companies have aggregate annual revenues of approximately $10.6 billion, operate 156 manufacturing facilities in 23 countries, and have approximately 40,000 employees, directly and through joint ventures worldwide. KPS, as a leading global investment firm, has a significant and longstanding presence in Europe, with offices in Amsterdam and Frankfurt. KPS' portfolio companies have 35 manufacturing facilities with 11,000 employees in Europe. KPS has a strong track record of realising improvements in manufacturing businesses and over two decades of constructive investing in highly complex corporate carve-outs on a global basis. KPS’ distinct and differentiated investment strategy has consistently resulted in the creation of world-class, industry-leading manufacturing companies. KPS has significant experience in the packaging industry having owned Anchor Glass Container, Blue Ridge Paper Products, Curtis Papers and Expera Specialty Solutions. Corporate carve-outs have represented over 50% of KPS’ platform investments and include carve-outs from leading global corporations such as AB InBev, Adidas, Ardagh Group, Baker Hughes, Bosch, Brunswick, Colfax, Cookson, Delphi, Dover, Dresser, Harris Teeter, Norsk Hydro, International Paper, Johnson Controls Olin Corporation, Packaging Dynamics, Schlumberger, Smurfit-Stone, Thyssen Krupp and Wausau Paper -----

Section Title: SUMMARY CORPORATE AND FINANCING STRUCTURE
Subsubsection Text: _The diagram below summarizes the Issuer’s corporate and financing structure on a pro forma basis to reflect the Transactions. For a summary of the material financing arrangements identified in this diagram, please refer to the sections captioned “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.” All company ownership is 100% unless otherwise indicated._ (1) As adjusted for the Transactions (and subject to ownership of Titan Group by Senior Management), the Sponsor and Crown will indirectly own 80.0% and 20.0% of the Issuer’s shares, respectively. (2) The Issuer will issue €375.0 million aggregate principal amount of Notes. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer and guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by Bidco. On the Completion Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Completion Guarantors. Within 90 days of the Completion Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by the Post-Completion Guarantors. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured on a first-ranking basis by the Escrow Charge. On or prior to the Completion Date, the Notes will be secured by (i) first-priority security interests over (a) all of the issued share capital of the Issuer held by Topco, (b) receivables in respect of certain material intercompany loans owed to Topco and (c) material bank accounts of the Issuer and (ii) second-priority security interests over (a) all of the issued share capital of Bidco held by the Issuer and (b) receivables in respect of certain material intercompany loans owed to the Issuer by Bidco (collectively, the “ Collateral”). See “ Description of the Notes—Security; the Collateral.” Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Guarantees will, subject to certain limitations, be subject to payment blockage, standstill and turnover provisions. See “ Description of Certain Financing and _Guarantee Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ (3) On or about the Issue Date, Bidco, as borrower, will enter into the Credit Facilities Agreement which provides for a €1,175.0 million term loan facility and a €275.0 million revolving credit facility. The term loan facility under the Credit Facilities Agreement will be drawn on or about the Completion ----- Date and the proceeds therefrom will be used to, among other things, consummate the Transactions on or about the Completion Date. We currently expect that the revolving credit facility under the Credit Facilities Agreement will be undrawn on the Completion Date. The Credit Facilities will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the same entities that will guarantee the Notes on a senior subordinated basis and will be secured on a first-priority basis, by the Shared Collateral, as well as, within 90 days of the Completion Date, by a pledge of the capital stock of each Guarantor, a pledge of certain material operating bank accounts of each Guarantor and certain intra-group receivables owing to each Guarantor and for each UK obligor, security over substantially all of its material assets. See “ Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Credit Facilities Agreement.” (4) As of and for the twelve months ended December 31, 2020, the Guarantors represented approximately 65% of EBITDA of the Titan Group, approximately 75% of net sales of the Titan Group and approximately 76% of total assets (excluding goodwill) of the Titan Group. The guarantees and security interest will be subject to certain limitations and to the agreed security principles as described in this Offering Memorandum. See “Description of the Notes— _Security; the Collateral.” The guarantees and security interest may be released under certain circumstances. See “ Description of the Notes—Release of Liens” and “Description of the Notes—Guarantees.”_ (5) On the Completion Date, the Issuer will lend the proceeds of the Notes to Bidco to be used to, among other things, consummate the Transactions. (6) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum. pro forma for the Transactions, the Issuer’s subsidiaries that will not Guarantee the Notes are not expected to have any material indebtedness for borrowed money outstanding. (7) Upon completion of the Transactions, the entities in the restricted group will be subject to the covenants set forth in the Indenture. On the Completion Date, none of the subsidiaries of the Issuer will be Unrestricted Subsidiaries. -----

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Redemption ..................................................** Concurrently with the closing of the Offering on the Issue Date, the Issuer will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account, to hold such amounts pending the consummation of the Acquisition. The Escrow Account will be in the name of the Issuer and will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and pledged on a first-ranking basis to the Trustee for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. See “Risk _Factors—Risks related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the Notes,”_ The release of the funds credited to the Escrow Account and the consummation of the Acquisition will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. Upon delivery to the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the Escrow Proceeds have been met or will be satisfied promptly following the release of the Escrow Proceeds, the Escrow Proceeds will be released to the Issuer and utilized as described in “Use of Proceeds” and “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” and the Escrow Charge will be released._ In the event that the Completion Date does not take place on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date, the Issuer will redeem the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the aggregate initial issue price of the Notes, plus accrued but unpaid interest from the Issue Date to, but not including the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined herein) (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date). See “Risk Factors—Risks ----- _related to the Notes—If the Acquisition is not completed, you may not obtain the return that you expect on the Notes,” and “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”_ In the event that the special mandatory redemption price payable upon a special mandatory redemption exceeds the Escrow Proceeds, the Sponsor will, pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter, be required to make an equity contribution to the Issuer to pay any funding shortfall to cover the accrued and unpaid interest, and Additional Amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes and any negative interest charged on the Escrow Account. See ‘‘Description of the Notes—Escrow of _Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.’’_ Change of Control .....................................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. A change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a certain consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded as a result of such event. See “Description of the Notes—Change of _Control.”_ In connection with a change of control offer for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such change of control offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a change of control offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer, or any third party making such a change of control offer in lieu of the Issuer, will have the right, upon prior notice to the holders, to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding following such purchase at a price equal to the price paid to each other holder of Notes in such change of control offer, plus, to the extent not included in the change of control offer payment, accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, thereon, to, but not including, the redemption date. Certain Covenants ......................................** The Indenture contains covenants that limit the ability of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries to, among other things: - incur or guarantee additional debt and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends or make other distributions or investments or purchase or reduce or redeem the Issuer’s stock; - make investments or other restricted payments; - enter into agreements that restrict the Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends; - transfer or sell assets; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness; - impair security interests; or - merge or consolidate with other entities or transfer all or substantially all of the Issuer’s or a Guarantor’s assets. ----- Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.” Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as the Group achieves investment grade ratings. See ‘‘Description of the Notes— _Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.’’_ Intercreditor Agreement ...........................** Each holder of a Note by accepting a Note will be deemed to have agreed to, and be bound by, the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The Indenture will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, and the rights and benefits of the holders of the Notes will be limited accordingly and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement.”_ Use of Proceeds...........................................** The Issuer will use the gross proceeds of the Notes as set forth in “Use _of Proceeds.”_ Transfer Restrictions.................................** The Issuer has not registered the Notes or the Guarantees under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any state of the United States or any other jurisdiction and has not agreed, or otherwise undertaken, to do so. You may only offer or sell Notes pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act. See “Transfer Restrictions.”

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Absence of a Public Market for the
Subsubsection Text: Notes ............................................................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuer that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, the Issuer cannot assure you as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes. Furthermore, the Notes will not have registration rights under the US Securities Act. Listing ..........................................................** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the ‘‘Authority’’) for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the ‘‘Exchange’’) and admission to trade on the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange.

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: _The summary below describes the principal terms of the Notes, the Guarantees, the Intercreditor Agreement and the Security Documents. It is not intended to be complete and certain of the terms and conditions described below are subject to important exceptions. You should carefully review the “Description of the Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” sections of this Offering Memorandum for more detailed descriptions of the terms and conditions of the Notes and the Intercreditor Agreement._ Issuer............................................................** Titan Holdings II B.V. Notes Offered .............................................** €375 million aggregate principal amount of Senior Notes due 2029 (the “Notes”). Issue Date ....................................................**, 2021 (the “Issue Date”). Issue Price ..................................................** % plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, from the Issue Date. Maturity Date .............................................**, 2029. Interest Payment Dates .............................** Interest on the Notes will be payable semi-annually in arrear on     and of each year, commencing on     . Interest on the Notes will accrue from the Issue Date. Denomination ..............................................** The Notes will have a minimum denomination of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. Ranking of the Notes..................................** The Notes will: - be senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth below under “—Security;” - rank at least pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future senior indebtedness and other liabilities that is not expressly subordinated to the Notes (save for any indebtedness and other obligations mandatorily preferred by law); - be effectively subordinated to all existing and future secured indebtedness and other obligations of the Issuer and its subsidiaries that are secured by assets that do not secure the Notes, or that are secured on a first-priority basis over assets that secure the notes on a second-priority basis (including the indebtedness incurred under the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations), to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness or such other obligations, and to any creditor having a preferred claim by operation of law, to the extent of the value of such preferred claim; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. The Notes will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement”_ and “Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ Guarantors ..................................................** The Senior Notes are expected to be guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by (i) on the Issue Date, Bidco (the “Initial Guarantor”), (ii) on the Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, certain ----- subsidiaries of the Issuer that will be obligors under the Credit Facilities Agreement (the “Completion Guarantors”) and (iii) within 90 days following the Completion Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the Credit Facilities Agreement by certain additional direct and indirect subsidiaries of the Issuer that guarantee the Credit Facilities Agreement (the “Post-Completion Guarantors”). As of and for the twelve months ended December 31, 2020, the Guarantors accounted for approximately 75% of the Titan Group’s net sales, approximately 65% of the Titan Group’s EBITDA and approximately 76% of the Titan Group’s total assets (excluding goodwill). The Guarantees will be subject to certain contractual and legal limitations, and may be released without the consent of holders of the Notes under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes— _Guarantees” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, pro forma for the Transactions, the Issuer’s subsidiaries that will not Guarantee the Notes are not expected to have any material indebtedness for borrowed money outstanding. Ranking of the Guarantees .......................** The Guarantee of each Guarantor will: - be a senior subordinated obligation of that Guarantor; - be subordinated in right of payment to all of the Guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness, including any indebtedness under or in respect of the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future senior subordinated indebtedness and other liabilities of that Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Guarantees; - be effectively subordinated to all existing and future secured Indebtedness and other obligations of such Guarantor that are secured by assets that do not secure its Guarantee or that are secured on a first-priority basis over assets that secure the Guarantees on a second-priority basis (including the Indebtedness Incurred under the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain Hedging Obligations), to the extent of the value of the assets securing such Indebtedness or such other obligations, and to any creditor having a preferred claim by operation of law, to the extent of the value of such preferred claim; - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not Guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors; and ----- - be subject to the limitations described under “Limitations on _Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ The Guarantees will be subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and may be released in certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Guarantees”, and “Description of Certain _Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ Security........................................................** On the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by the Escrow Charge. Upon the definitive release of the Escrow Proceeds, the first-priority security interests over the Escrow Proceeds will be released. On or prior to the Completion Date, to the extent legally possible and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be secured by (collectively, the “Collateral”): - a first-ranking security interest in (1) a pledge of shares held in the Issuer by Topco; (2) a pledge of the receivables in respect of certain material intercompany loans owed to Topco, if any; and (3) a pledge of material operating bank accounts of the Issuer; and - a second-ranking security interest in (1) a pledge of shares held in Bidco by the Issuer; and (2) a pledge of receivables in respect of certain material intercompany loans owed to the Issuer by Bidco (items 1 and 2 collectively, the “Shared Collateral”). The Shared Collateral will also secure on a first-ranking basis the Credit Facilities Agreement and certain hedging obligations and may also secure certain future indebtedness. The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Security; the Collateral.” The security interests in the Collateral will be subject to the limitations described under “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the _Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ Additional Amounts ..................................** Any payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of taxes unless required by law. If the Issuer or Guarantors are required by law to withhold or deduct amounts for or on account of tax imposed or levied by a relevant Tax Jurisdiction with respect to a payment to the holders of the Notes, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to certain exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the _Notes—Additional Amounts.”_ Optional Redemption .................................** At any time prior to     , 2024, the Issuer may on any one or more occasions redeem all or a part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the aggregate principal amount thereof redeemed, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium (described in this Offering Memorandum) and accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. ----- At any time prior to     , 2024, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including additional notes, if any) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to      % of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes remains outstanding immediately following the redemption. At any time prior to    , 2024, the Issuer may, during each twelvemonth period commencing with the issue date, redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including additional notes, if any) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time on or after    , 2024, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the caption “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption” and Additional Amounts if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Optional Redemption for Tax Reasons...** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but not including, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption for _Tax Reasons.”_

EBITDA represents operating income/(loss) plus depreciation and amortization. Adjusted EBITDA represents EBITDA as adjusted for certain non-operating and non-recurring items as set forth below. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA represents Adjusted EBITDA on a pro forma basis for estimated procurement savings. We believe that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA provide useful information as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. We note, however, that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies, should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for an analysis of our operating results as reported under U.S. GAAP and have limitations as analytical tools. Some of these limitations include the following: (i) they do not reflect capital expenditures, future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; (ii) they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, working capital needs; (iii) they do not reflect interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on debt; and (iv) although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often need to be replaced in the future and do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements. See “ Presentation of Financial and Other _Information – Alternative performance measures (“APMs”)” and “ Risk Factors –Risks Relating to the Acquisition – Titan Group’s ability to operate its business effectively may suffer if it is unable to cost-effectively establish its own administrative and other support functions in order to operate as a standalone company after the expiration of the Transitional Services Agreement with the Crown Group.”_ The calculations for Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are based on various assumptions, management estimates and unaudited management accounts. These amounts have not been audited, reviewed or verified by any independent accounting firm. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations of the transactions for the periods presented and may not be comparable to our combined financial statements or other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. We present EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA because we believe they are helpful to investors as measures of our operating performance and ability to service our debt. Subsubsection Text: _Pro Forma for:_ Pro Forma Procurement Savings[(j)] .................... 13 **PRO FORMA ADJUSTED EBITDA.............** ----- **317** (a) This amount represents that portion of the historical costs and expenses of Crown assigned to Titan Group in the Audited Combined Financial Statements and Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements using an allocation method primarily based on percentage of sales, including expenses for executive management, finance, legal, information technology, employee benefit administration, treasury and risk management as well as technology royalties. (b) This amount represents the costs and expenses required to operate the Group on a standalone basis. These costs cover substantially the same categories that comprise the amounts under “ Discontinued Corporate Allocations”. Standalone costs are expected to be significantly less than costs incurred under the Discontinued Corporate Allocations. See “ Risk Factors — Risks Relating to the Acquisition — Titan Group’s ability to _operate its business effectively may suffer if it is unable to cost-effectively establish its own administrative and other support functions in order to operate as a standalone company after the expiration of the Transitional Services Agreement with the Crown Group.” Standalone costs are_ based on management estimates and assumptions (including the successful implementation of our standalone strategy) and are forward looking in nature. As such, this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our estimates. Any failure by us to successfully execute on our standalone strategy could materially impact our results. As such, this information is inherently subject to business, economic and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our estimated standalone costs and expenses. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial impact or results of these actions and initiatives and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. If one or more of our underlying assumptions proves to have been incorrect, this could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated time frame, the estimated benefits from our standalone cost-savings. See "Risk Factors — Risks Relating to the _Acquisition — Titan Group has no operating history as a standalone company and it may not be successful in implementing its strategy as a standalone business."_ (c) Following the Completion Date, the Business will operate on a stand-alone basis independently of its United States parent. Given that none of the Group’s operations are in the United States, we expect that our reporting currency will shift from the U.S. Dollar to the Euro and we anticipate preparing our financial statements under IFRS. The amounts in this line item represent the estimated impact of operating lease expenses recognized under IFRS 16, which introduces a single, on-balance sheet lease accounting model for lessees. The amounts in this line item represent the U.S. GAAP operating lease expense from the Audited Combined Financial Statements as a proxy for the IFRS 16 lease liabilities. See Annex A for a discussion of certain differences between U.S. GAAP and IFRS. A lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease liability representing its obligations to make lease payments. There are optional exemptions for short-term leases and leases of low value items. (d) This adjustment in the year ended December 31, 2019 primarily relates to a $25 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge, incurred related primarily to our aerosols and promotional packaging activities, resulting from the outlook for tinplate aerosol packaging having declined and operating costs in the aerosol and promotional packaging activities having increased, as well as an $8 million restructuring add-back and a $3 million loss on disposal. The adjustment in the year ended December 31, 2020 primarily relates to a $2 million gain on disposal. The Business has undergone a variety of restructuring efforts, primarily related to plant closures in France and Germany in an effort to reduce overall fixed headcount and duplicative positions. Restructuring costs included in this adjustment take account of severance and other general cost associated with implementing the restructuring such as cleaning or stripping plants. (e) Represents the removal of non-operating costs included in pension expense, in particular amortization of prior year unrealized losses related to German pensions. (f) Represents costs associated with discontinued operations in Peru, primarily comprised of VAT expenses and operating losses. The facility in Peru is not part of the Titan Group going forward. (g) This amount normalizes the impact of bad debt expense to $1.1 million per annum based on historical bad debt expense accruals, run-rate and relatively consistent sales year over year over a period of 10 years. (h) Represents (i) expenses in relation to the implementation of a new information technology system in the year ended December 31, 2018 leading to more precise methodologies in monitoring inventory, (ii) recoveries of customer claims from suppliers in relation to defective products, (iii) removal of EBITDA relating to a customer contract which was discontinued in the year ended December 31, 2018, and (iv) normalizing costs in relation to the Business’ UK pension system due to a change from a defined benefit plan to a defined contribution plan in the year ended December 31, 2019. (i) Our Adjusted EBITDA margin amounted to 13.5%, 11.6%, 12.0% for the year ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively, and 8.5% and 14.3% for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. (j) This amount represents estimated savings expected to be realized in connection with procurement initiatives for raw materials, in particular tinplate through, inter alia, negotiation of price discounts in place of long payment terms and intensifying cross-functional cooperation to harmonize specifications of raw materials. Pro forma procurement savings are based on management estimates and assumptions (including the successful implementation of certain initiatives) and are forward-looking in nature. As such, this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our estimates. Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve procurement efficiencies could materially impact our results. See “ Risk Factors – Titan Group has no operating _history as a standalone company and it may not be successful in implementing its strategy as a standalone business.”_ (k) Not meaningful. (2) Adjusted EBITDA margin represents Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin represents Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales. ----- (3) Capital expenditure includes both maintenance and growth capital expenditure. In the years ended December 31, 2018 to December 31, 2020, growth capital expenditure represented on average approximately 10% of capital expenditures. (4) Free cash flow represents Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditures. (5) Cash conversion represents free cash flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA. (6) Volumes represents the number of units sold of food cans only. (7) Pro forma net debt represents our net debt on a pro forma basis for the Transaction, including an aggregate of €375 million under the Notes offered hereby. See “ Capitalization.” Pro forma net debt is presented for illustrative purposes only and is based on a convenience translation of Euro to US Dollar of 1:1.1728. (8) Pro forma net secured debt represents the Term Loan B Facility net of pro forma cash and cash equivalents. See “ Capitalization.” Pro forma net secured debt is presented for illustrative purposes only and is based on a convenience translation of Euro to US Dollar of 1:1.1728. (9) Pro forma cash interest expense represents cash pay interest payable under the Credit Facilities Agreement (including the Term Loan B Facility but not including the Revolving Credit Facility) and the cash pay interest payable in respect of the Notes as if the Transaction had occurred on April 1, 2020. This amount does not include any interest on lease liabilities, or any commitment or utilization fees associated with the Senior Facilities Agreement and assumes an imputed weighted average interest rate for the Term Loan B Facility. Pro forma cash interest expense is presented for illustrative purposes only and is based on a convenience translation of Euro to US Dollar of 1:1.162. The Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements included in this Offering Memorandum are based on U.S. GAAP, which differs in certain respects from IFRS. For a discussion of certain significant differences between U.S. GAAP and IFRS, see Annex A. Management has undertaken a preliminary analysis to assess the potential impact on the Group’s financial position, results of operations and cash flows from a change from U.S. GAAP to IFRS. Management has determined that the application of IFRS 16 is expected to impact the Group's treatment of leases, in particular with respect to the income statement. For the estimated impact of the application of IFRS 16 on the Group's Adjusted EBITDA, see “Summary Financial and Other Information.” While Management believes that the application of IFRS 16 will be the main impact to the Group’s financial position, results of operations and cash flows as a result of the change from U.S. GAAP to IFRS, the Group has not prepared and is not presenting a reconciliation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Combined Consolidated Financial Statements to IFRS in this Offering Memorandum, and it is possible that such a change could lead to other differences to the Group’s financial position, results of operations and cash flows from the amounts presented in this Offering Memorandum. See “Risk Factors – The Financial Statements are based _on U.S. GAAP and there may be differences between our financial position and results of operations prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP and IFRS. In addition, should Titan Group decide to adopt IFRS as its accounting reporting method, this could potentially result in material changes to certain of its financial information from the information presented in this Offering Memorandum.”_ ----- Following the Completion Date, the Business will no longer be part of the Crown Group and hence will be operated independently from its United States parent. Given that none of the Group’s operations are in the United States, we expect that our reporting currency will shift from the U.S. Dollar to the Euro, representing the functional currency in a majority of the jurisdictions in which we operate. Therefore, we have included below a convenience translation into the Euro, based on the exchange rates derived from Titan Group’s accounting systems or, in the case of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, the average exchange rate for the twelve months period ended March 31, 2021 based on market observable rates, of the summary financial data included above which is presented for illustrative purposes only. Footnotes to the tables have not been repeated or separately translated into Euro. See “Presentation of Financial Information – Convenience Translation”.
