Subsubsection Text: _The Issuer is a holding company formed for the purpose of facilitating the Acquisition and is not expected to engage in any activities other than those related to the Acquisition. We do not present in this Offering Memorandum any financial information or financial statements of the Issuer. The following tables present selected consolidated historical financial information and other data as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and as of and for the three months ended March 31, 2020 and 2021, which have been derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. The selected financial data in the tables below should be read together with the Audited Combined Financial Statements including the notes thereto, which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Risk Factors,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and “Capitalization.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the 26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain. We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe. Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: 1. According to leading global consulting firm 2. According to Management estimates We sell our products in more than 90 countries with France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany representing 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of our sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and other geographies making up the remaining 41% of sales in the same period. Sales to our top 10 customers represented just 32% of our total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers for an average of over 25 years. Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European tinplate packaging industry. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $303 million, $247 million and $267 million, respectively. Our net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were $2,297 million and $317 million, respectively, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. These amounts translate, for convenience purposes only, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, to net sales of €1,897 million, €1,910 million and €1,951 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of €256 million, €221 million and €234 million, respectively, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of €1,974 million and €272 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on production and aggregate demand became apparent in all economies. In leading global economies, authorities enacted strong expansionary measures to provide income support to households and firms, provide credit to the economy and bolster market liquidity. The spread of the virus in Europe since the end of February 2020 and the measures adopted to reduce the rate of infection had significant repercussions on economic activity in the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021. In relation to the Group, the COVID-19 pandemic generated a modest increase in canned food consumption due to more at-home eating, which was partially offset by lower sales of large format cans for the food services industry. In addition, demand for aerosols packaging declined as personal care habits changed during the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales of promotional packaging also declined as marketplaces such as airport shops where such packaging is sold were closed. Overall, we estimate that benefits due to increases in demand for food cans offset losses in volume in our aerosols and promotional packaging activities and increased expenditures, resulting in a net neutral impact to our financial performance. Our manufacturing facilities were deemed system relevant in each jurisdiction in which we operate and remained fully operational throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Our office workforce experienced no disruption since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic due to our ability to swiftly switch all platforms and processes to be functional remotely and to promptly enhance communication channels. Even before the restrictive measures in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic came into effect, we adopted a series of further, voluntary and increasingly stringent precautionary measures in addition to those required by law, with a view to ensuring a greater degree of protection for employees. We leveraged the use of smart working arrangements for those activities that can be carried out remotely, and vacation and paid leave were incentivized. In addition, we took advantage of social safety-net arrangements as appropriate, in conjunction with the introduction of anti-contagion safety protocols, use of personal protection equipment and sanitization of business premises.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Demand for some of our products is seasonal. At least 45% of our revenue is generated from sales to seasonal food end-markets. The industry enters its busiest period in the third quarter when the majority of seasonal fruits and vegetables are harvested. Due to the foregoing factors our working capital requirements typically build during the first half of a financial year and decrease during the second half of a financial year. Inventory levels typically increase in the first half of the year to meet peak demand in the second and third quarters. Our results of operations, cash flows and liquidity may therefore be impacted by these seasonal practices.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Weather conditions can reduce crop yields and adversely affect customer demand for fruit and vegetable cans in any given year. In addition, demand for our seafood packaging is affected by variation in local fish catches. Severe weather conditions associated with climate change such as droughts, hail, floods or frost, are unpredictable and may potentially impact agricultural production which in turn may lead to reduced demand for our products in the regions in which we currently operate. See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's business is seasonal and adverse weather conditions could reduce Titan Group's net _sales.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Raw materials constitute the substantial majority of our production cost and our total costs of raw materials were $1,196 million, $1,148 million and $1,159 million, or 53.7%, 53.7% and 51.7%, respectively, of our net sales for the year ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our key raw material input is steel (both tinplate and tin-free forms), which constituted 48.5%, 51.2% and 49.2% of the total cost of goods sold for the year ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. We believe we are the largest purchaser of tinplate steel in Europe. Our relationships with domestic European steel mills are a key strength of our business and represent a critical strategic advantage compared to our competitors. The cost of steel is affected by a variety of micro and macro factors, primarily based on the supply and demand for steel, market movements in other base metals and geopolitical factors. Importantly, steel is generally purchased under one-year contracts with prices that are fixed for each calendar year, minimizing the intra-year volatility of our primary input cost. We have not experienced any material supply issues related to our key raw materials that impacted our ability to meet customer demand requirements during the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that our strong relationships with the leading European suppliers of steel, including committed volume contracts, have allowed us to source steel consistently through a variety of market conditions. We also believe that certain of our competitors are experiencing difficulties in purchasing these raw materials because of a lack of scale. We centrally manage our procurement operations across the Group in order to achieve ----- economies of scale, seek consistency across our relationships across Europe, the Middle East and Africa and provide more certainty for production planning. Changes in the cost of raw materials affect both our net sales and our cost of materials and thus substantially affect our results of operations. However, the price for steel is not often a substantial factor affecting our underlying business performance as we typically pass-through any increases in raw material prices to our customers. Through a combination of contracts which include input cost pass-through provisions and annual price negotiations which also reflect tinplate prices, we have historically been able to minimize margin volatility due to changes in raw material costs. We pass through changes in raw material costs relating to the remainder of our business’s revenues through annual pricing negotiations. Since steel prices are also contracted for on an annual basis, our customer pricing and raw material input cost changes are generally matched. We have been generally able to successfully pass through raw material price fluctuations and maintain largely consistent margins throughout much of our operating history. However, in 2019, Titan offered certain price concessions to capture wallet share and long long-term contracts. This improved revenue certainty at the expense of short short-term margins.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: During the periods discussed herein, our reporting currency was the U.S. Dollar, however our sales and revenue and operating costs are realized in other currencies, predominantly the Euro, which represents approximately 74% of our revenue. As a result, our historical financials are exposed to foreign exchange translation fluctuations between such other currencies and the U.S. Dollar. The translation of foreign currencies back to the U.S. Dollar may have a significant impact on our revenues and financial results. Foreign exchange has an unfavorable impact on revenues when the U.S. Dollar is relatively strong as compared with foreign currencies and a favorable impact on revenues when the U.S. Dollar is relatively weak as compared with foreign currencies. Our business has a limited level of transactional currency exposure arising from sales or purchases by operating activities in currencies other than their functional currencies. Assets and liabilities of the Group denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar, were translated to U.S. Dollar using the applicable period-end rates of exchange. To counteract seasonal effects, the income, expense and cash flow items were translated to U.S. Dollar at average exchange rates prevailing throughout the applicable period. Translation adjustments are accumulated as a separate component of other comprehensive income (loss). Following the Completion Date, the Business will no longer be part of the Crown Group and hence will be operated independently from its United States parent. Given that none of the Group’s operations are in the United States, we expect that our reporting currency will shift from the U.S. Dollar to the Euro, representing the functional currency in a majority of the jurisdictions in which we operate. While we will remain subject to limited foreign exchange transaction risk, such shift would eliminate the risk arising from currency translation to the U.S. Dollar. We expect this change in reporting currency to have a positive impact on the stability and comparability of our results of operations going forward.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Steel and aluminum packaging is environmentally sustainable. Not only are steel and aluminum infinitely recyclable, but they also have the highest recycling rates amongst packaging formats. Additionally, according to the Can Manufacturing Institute, recycling saves up to 75% of the energy required to produce virgin steel. Greater environmental consciousness and strong sustainability trends have led to an increased preference for recyclable packaging. Consumers increasingly view sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging, which has been further reinforced by regulatory developments. Changes in regulations and ability to reuse materials and produce packaging that is perceived as environmentally friendly can affect both our net sales and our cost of materials and thus substantially affect our results of operations. Metal packaging’s properties position it to benefit from the increasing backlash against the use of plastic products.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The following are a description of the main factors which have affected our financial condition and results of operations for the three-months period ended March 31, 2020 and 2021 and for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, as well as certain factors which are expected to impact our financial condition and results of operations in the future. The businesses, operations, assets and liabilities comprising the Titan Group have historically operated as part and under the umbrella of the global Crown Group, which provided substantial management and shared services to the business. Upon completion of the Acquisition, Titan Group will operate on a standalone basis. We have no history operating as a standalone group, see also “Risk Factors––We have no operating history as a standalone company.” Consequently, our future results of operations will exclude cost historically allocated to Titan Group by Crown and will include costs and expenses for us to operate as a standalone business, and we expect these costs and expenses to be materially different than our historical cost structure. We will also incur a significant amount of debt in connection with the Transactions. Accordingly, our historical results presented in this Offering Memorandum are not indicative of our future results of operations, financial positions and cash flows. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Net sales consist of gross sales less sales adjustments related to provisions for customer returns, allowances, rebates, pass-through taxes and eliminations of intra-group transactions. We disaggregate net sales based on the timing of transfer of control for goods and services. The transfer of control for goods and services may occur at a point in time or over time; in other ----- words, sales may be recognized over the course of the underlying contract, or they may occur at a single point in time based upon the transfer of control.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Costs of products sold includes fixed and variable production costs. Such variable costs mainly consist of the costs of raw materials, realized effective hedges related to commodity hedges, unrealized and realized ineffective hedges related to commodity hedges, energy, freight, utilities, handling and conversion costs, waste disposal, consumables, attributable depreciation charges and directly attributable overhead expenses, including wages and salaries and overhead expenses that are attributable to production. Due to the seasonal demand of our business, we utilize temporary labor to scale production to meet customer demand. Changes in variable costs relating to raw material prices are generally passed through to customers. Fixed costs include a portion of overhead labor costs, as well as rent, impairment of inventories, repairs and maintenance.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation and amortization relates to the depreciation of property, plant and equipment and the amortization of intangible assets. Depreciation and amortization is accounted for on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets. The Group periodically reviews the estimated useful lives of its plant, property and equipment and, where appropriate, changes are made prospectively. Definite-lived intangible assets are tested for impairment when facts and circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable from their undiscounted cash flows.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Selling expenses include all selling costs. During the periods presented herein, Selling costs comprise the sales and customer service activities of the organization. Administrative expenses typically include advertising costs, insurance costs, legal and professional fees, office supplies, design and development cost, sales and marketing costs, finance costs, information technology, human resources and other administrative costs. As from the Closing Date, certain allocated administrative expenses of our current United States parent will not continue, while some allocated charges will need to be replicated by costs going forward. Please refer to the reconciliation of Adjusted EBITDA included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for further detail. See “Summary Financial and Other _Information.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Technology royalty refers to an intragroup charge to Crown for general research and development and overall business processes for the periods presented herein. From the Closing Date onwards, this charge to Crown will discontinue.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Restructuring costs relate to reduction of manufacturing capacity and headcount across the Group. Other relates to asset impairments and gains on the sale of assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill impairment relates to impairment charges where an asset’s carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount. Goodwill is carried at cost and reviewed for impairment annually in the fourth quarter of each year or when facts and circumstances indicate goodwill may be impaired.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Interest expense relates to interest expenses from our intragroup and external financings including bank borrowings, interest expense associated with accounts receivable factoring and securitization programs, trade bills and other financial expenses. Other expenses relates to pension and related non-services costs as well as foreign exchange gains or losses. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expenses consist of current tax expense and deferred tax expense. Deferred taxes represent the future expected tax consequences of differences between the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities based upon enacted tax rates and laws. Valuation allowances are recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will not be realized. Investment tax credits are accounted for using the deferral method. Income tax-related interest and penalties are reported as income tax expense. The Group’s effective tax rate (calculated as income taxes divided by income before income taxes) was 27.9% for the year ended December 31, 2020, 30.7% for the year ended December 31, 2019, and 24.0% for the year ended December 31, 2018. The Group’s effective income tax rate fluctuates based on, among other factors, the geographic mix of earnings. The higher effective income tax rate in 2019 is related to a $25 million non-deductible impairment charge primarily related to our aerosols and promotional packaging activities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Title: Net Income Attributable to Noncontrolling Interests
Subsubsection Text: We consolidate entities in which we own or control more than fifty percent of voting shares or otherwise have a controlling financial interest in the entity. We consider ourselves to have a controlling financial interest in the entity if we have (1) the power to direct the activities of the entity that most significantly impact the entity’s economic performance and (2) the obligation to absorb losses of the entity that could potentially be significant to the entity or the right to receive benefits from the entity that could potentially be significant to the entity. The net income attributable to noncontrolling interests refers to the share of profit belonging to the minority shareholders of the entity which is controlled by the Group, but for which only a portion of earnings are returned to the Group. The portion returned reflects the percentage of entity ownership. In this case, the Group’s line item represents the share of profit belonging to the minority shareholders of the Group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin
Subsubsection Text: We calculate EBITDA as net income before provision of income taxes, interest expense, depreciation and amortization. EBITDA is not a measurement of performance under US GAAP and investors should not consider EBITDA as an alternative ----- to income from operations as an indicator of our operating performance, or an alternative to cash flow from operating activities as a measure of our liquidity. We calculate Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for non-operating or non-recurring items to EBITDA. We calculate Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA by applying adjustments for the benefit of cost savings from operational improvement opportunities that we expect to realize within the next three years. We calculate Adjusted EBITDA margin as Adjusted EBITDA divided by net sales. We believe that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin are meaningful for investors because they provide an analysis of our operating results, profitability and ability to service debt and because they are used by our chief operating decision makers to track our business evolution, establish operational and strategic targets and make important business decisions. To facilitate the analysis of our operations, EBITDA excludes amortization, impairment and depreciation expenses from income from operations in order to eliminate the impact of general long term capital investment. The following table sets forth a reconciliation of EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA to our net income for the periods discussed herein.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Below is a discussion of certain non-US GAAP financial information. Such financial information is not defined under US GAAP, and other companies may calculate such financial information differently or may use such measures for different purposes, limiting the usefulness of such measures as comparative measures. The APMs should not be considered in isolation and investors should not consider such information as alternative to net income as an indicator of our financial performance, an alternative to income from operations as an indicator of our operating performance, or an alternative to cash flows from operating activities as a measure of our liquidity. Such financial information must be considered only in addition to, and not as a substitute for or superior to, financial information prepared in accordance with US GAAP included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Investors are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these APMs and are also advised to review them in conjunction with the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This Offering Memorandum contains financial measures that are not defined or recognized under US GAAP, including: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA margin. We present these APMs because we believe that they contribute to a better understanding of our results of operations by providing additional information on what we consider some of the drivers of our financial performance. Furthermore, we believe that these APMs are widely used by certain investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as supplemental measures of performance and liquidity. In addition, the presentation of these measures is not intended to and does not necessarily comply with the reporting requirements of the SEC; compliance with its requirements would require us to make changes to the presentation of this information. We believe that the description of these APMs in this Offering Memorandum follows and complies with the European Securities and Markets Authority Guidelines on Alternative Performance Measures dated October 5, 2015. See also “Presentation of Financial Information––Alternative performance measures (“APMs”).”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Net sales_ Our net sales increased by $70 million, or 15.2%, to $530 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $460 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher sales volume in the seasonal foods end markets, including fruits and vegetables, with food can volumes increasing 8.5% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020, in light of suppressed volumes for the three months ended March 31, 2020 during the initial stages of the COVID-19 pandemic, which have normalized for the three months ended March 31, 2021. These trends were offset by lower sales volume in the fish end market for the three months ended March 31, 2021. _Costs of products sold_ Costs of products sold increased by $38 million, or 9.6%, to $434 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $396 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. Our costs of products sold as a percentage of net sales decreased by 4.2 percentage points to 81.9% for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from 86.1% for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to an inventory pricing headwind in the three months ended March 31, 2020 caused by a weaker than expected harvest in 2019 which did not repeat in the three months ended March 31, 2021. _Depreciation and amortization_ Depreciation and amortization increased by $1 million, or 7.1%, to $15 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $14 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely as a result of foreign currency translation, with the Euro appreciating by 9.4% compared to the same period of the prior year. ----- _Selling and administrative expenses_ Selling and administrative expenses increased by $1 million, or 3.8%, to $27 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $26 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to foreign currency translation. The underlying selling and administrative expenses in the operating currencies were lower in the three months ended March 31, 2021 than in the same period of the prior year. _Technology royalty_ Technology royalty increased by $1 million, or 20.0%, to $6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to the increase in sales and associated increased cost allocation. These expenses will not continue to be charged from Crown to the Business following the Completion Date. _Restructuring and other_ We incurred $1 million of restructuring and other costs in the three months ended March 31, 2020 which were primarily related to a loss on disposal of certain assets. We did not incur any such costs in the three months ended March 31, 2021. _Income from operations_ Income from operations increased by $30 million, or 166.7%, to $48 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $18 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to higher sales, lower cost of products sold, lower selling and administrative expenses and foreign currency translation impact. _Interest expense_ Interest expense increased by $1 million, or 100%, to $2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 from $1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. _Provision for income taxes_ Provision for income taxes increased by $4 million, or 66.7%, to $10 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, from $6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, largely due to higher income from operations. _Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests_ Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests amounted to $1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, primarily attributable to increased income in our Morocco business due to an increase in volume from a rebound in the fishing industry, partially offset by foreign exchange impact. We reported no net income attributable to noncontrolling interests for the three months ended March 31, 2020. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: d f 5 4 5 4 _Net sales_ Our net sales increased by $89 million, or 4.2%, to $2,227 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $2,138 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher sales unit volumes, with food can volumes increasing 7.1% for the year ended December 31, 2020 relative to the prior year due to increased sales of smaller format cans, a better harvest relative to the prior year, as well as a positive impact of foreign currency translation. These impacts were partially offset by the pass-through of lower raw material costs, as changes in raw material costs impact revenue levels by a corresponding amount when they are passed through. _Costs of products sold_ Costs of products sold increased by $62 million, or 3.4%, to $1,867 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $1,805 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Our cost of products sold as a percentage of net sales decreased by 0.6 percentage points to 83.8% for the year ended December 31, 2020 from 84.4% for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to operating cost reductions as a result of our continuous improvement initiatives. _Depreciation and amortization_ Depreciation and amortization were effectively flat year-over-year, increasing $1 million, or 1.7% to $59 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $58 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, largely as a result of foreign currency translation, with the Euro appreciating by 1.9% compared to the prior year period. ----- _Selling and administrative expenses_ Selling and administrative expenses increased by $7 million, or 6.7%, to $112 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $105 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, largely due to higher sales expense from increased net sales, as well as the impact of foreign currency translation. _Technology royalty_ Technology royalty decreased by $2 million, or 7.1%, to $26 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $28 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, largely due to the change in type of sales by country and associated change in allocation. These expenses will not continue to be charged from Crown to the Business following the Completion Date. _Restructuring and other_ Restructuring and other costs decreased by $3 million, or 60.0%, to $2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Restructuring costs in each year related to headcount reductions at certain facilities. In the year ended December 31, 2019, these costs were partially offset by gains on the sale of various assets across the Group’s operations. _Goodwill impairment_ We recorded no goodwill impairment in the year ended December 31, 2020, whereas we recorded $25 million goodwill impairment in the year ended December 31, 2019 related primarily to our aerosols and promotional packaging activities. Please refer to the comparison of results for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018 for additional detail on this goodwill impairment. _Income from operations_ Income from operations increased by $49 million, or 43.8%, to $161 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from $112 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to higher sales volume and the one time goodwill impairment charge that only impacted the year ended December 31, 2019. _Interest expense_ Interest expense was stable at $9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. _Provision for income taxes_ Provision for income taxes increased by $10 million, or 32.3%, to $41 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from $31 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, as the goodwill impairment charge did not recur in the year December 31, 2020. _Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests_ Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests decreased by $1 million, or 50.0%, to $1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, from $2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily driven by lower income in our Morocco business due to a decrease in volume from a temporary downturn in the fishing industry. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: d f 5 4 5 4 _Net sales_ Our net sales decreased by $103 million, or 4.6%, to $2,138 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from $2,241 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to the impact of foreign currency translation and lower sales volume due to lower crop yields with food can volumes increasing only 1.4% for the year ended December 31, 2019 relative to the prior year, partially offset by the pass-through of higher raw material costs. Moreover, we granted price concessions to certain customers in the year ended December 31, 2019, which led to lower net sales in that year but to increased volumes over the long-term. _Cost of products sold_ Costs of products sold decreased by $38 million, or 2.1%, to $1,805 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from $1,843 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our cost of products sold as a percentage of net sales increased by 2.2 percentage points to 84.4% for the year ended December 31, 2019 from 82.2% for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased raw material costs, including tinplate steel and other non-metal raw materials, as well as increases in labour, energy and freight and other costs, offset by operating cost reductions as a result of our continuous improvement initiatives. Management decided not to pass-through the increased raw material costs to customers in an effort to gain market share. _Depreciation and amortization_ Depreciation and amortization were effectively flat at $58 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 relative to $60 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. ----- _Selling and administrative expenses_ Selling and administrative expenses decreased by $6 million, or 5.4%, to $105 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from $111 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, largely due to lower selling expenses associated with lower sales volumes, as well as cost saving initiatives implemented in the year. _Technology royalty_ Technology royalty increased by $2 million, or 7.7%, to $28 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from $26 million for the year ended December 31, 2018 largely due to the change in type of sales by country and associated change in allocation. These expenses will not continue to be charged from Crown to the Business following the Completion Date. _Restructuring and other_ Restructuring and other costs increased by $9 million to a cost of $5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from gains of $4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, which were due to the sale of two food can facilities in the United Kingdom which more than offset restructuring costs associated with headcount reductions. _Goodwill impairment_ We recorded no goodwill impairment in the year ended December 31, 2018, whereas we recorded a $25 million noncash goodwill impairment charge in the year ended December 31, 2019 related to our aerosols and promotional packaging activities, resulting from a determination that fair value had declined below its carrying value due to the outlook for tinplate steel aerosol packaging having declined and operating costs in the aerosol and promotional packaging activities having increased. _Income from operations_ Income from operations decreased by $93 million, or 45.4%, to $112 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from $205 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to reduced sales and a goodwill impairment charge incurred in the year ended December 31, 2019. _Interest expense_ Interest expense decreased by $2 million, or 18.2%, to $9 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from $11 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. _Provision for income taxes_ Provision for income taxes decreased by $13 million, or 29.5%, to $31 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from $44 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, largely due to reduced income from operations. _Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests_ Net income attributable to noncontrolling interests increased by $1 million, or 100.0%, to $2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, from $1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily driven by higher income in our Morocco business due to an increase in volume, partially offset by an accounting adjustment in post-retirement benefits and foreign exchange impact.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Before entering into the Financing, the primary sources of liquidity for our business have been cash flow from operating activities and the existing revolving credit facilities of the Crown Group. Following completion of the Financing, we expect that our primary source of liquidity will be cash flows from operating activities and the Revolving Credit Facility. It is expected that, as of the Completion Date, the Revolving Credit Facility will be undrawn except that in the event that freely available cash on the balance sheet on or about the Completion Date is lower than our estimate or insufficient to support our working capital requirements due to, among other things, a negative movement in working capital, we may draw down amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date or shortly thereafter. We have used our cash flow to fund operating expenses, working capital, capital expenditures, and capital and interest payments related to our debt obligations. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations together with available borrowings and cash on hand, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes offered hereby, or to fund our other liquidity needs. We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include: - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of operating profit from our operations, which could be caused by a downturn in our performance, the industry as a whole or the economy as a whole; - the failure or delay of our customers to make payments due to us; - the failure to maintain low working capital requirements; and - the need to fund expansion and other development capital expenditures. - If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures; - sell our assets; - obtain additional debt or equity financing; and/or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. ----- We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Notes and any future debt may limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to three months ended March 31, 2020_ Our net cash used for operating activities was $183 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, representing a decrease of $25 million compared to the prior year, primarily attributable to higher sales volume and improved profitability. Our net cash used in investing activities was $11 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, representing an increase of $8 million compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily attributable to capital expenditures relating to the development of a new facility in Russia and improvement of existing manufacturing capabilities. Our net cash provided by financing activities was $193 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, compared to $202 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily attributable to intercompany loans from Crown. ----- _Year ended December 31, 2020 compared to year ended December 31, 2019_ Our net cash generated by operating activities was $184 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, representing an increase of $33 million compared to the prior year. The increase in cash generated by operating activities was primarily driven by improved working capital management, particularly our ability to reduce inventory. Our net cash used in investing activities was $31 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, representing a decrease of $6 million compared to the prior year, primarily attributable to a decrease in capital expenditures, partially offset by sales of assets and equipment. Our net cash used in financing activities was $150 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, representing a decrease of $127 million compared to the prior year, primarily attributable to a reduction in our regular cash transfers to Crown. _Year ended December 31, 2019 compared to year ended December 31, 2018_ Our net cash generated by operating activities was $151 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a decrease of $79 million compared to the prior year. The decrease in cash generated by operating activities was primarily related to lower cash generated from net working capital in the year, as well as the lower profit generated in 2019 relative to prior year. Our net cash used in investing activities was $37 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, representing an increase of $10 million compared to the prior year, primarily attributable to an increase in capital expenditures, partially offset by sales of assets and equipment. Our net cash used in financing activities was $277 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, representing an increase of $86 million compared to the prior year, primarily attributable to an increase in our regular cash transfers to Crown.

See “—Key Factors _Affecting Our Results of Operations—Seasonality.” Changes in working capital are primarily due to the timing of our inventory_ build and raw material purchases relative to our customer sales and associated collections.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Changes in working capital are measured as the changes in assets and liabilities in a period, as presented in our combined statement of cash flows in the Audited Combined Financial Statements and our Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements. For the three months ended March 31, 2021 and 2020 and the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, our movements in net working capital were $(242) million, $(231) million, $34 million, $(1) million and $39 million, respectively. The increase in working capital spend from the three months ended March 31, 2020 to the three months ended March 31, 2021 was primarily due to an increase in inventory net of increase in trade payables. The decrease in working capital spend from the year ended December 31, 2019 to the year ended December 31, 2020 was a result of a reduction in inventory offset by an increase in trade and other receivables. The slight increase in working capital spend from the year ended December 31, 2018 to the year ended December 31, 2019 was a result of an increase in inventory offset by an increase in trade and other payables. We anticipate that our working capital requirements in the foreseeable future will generally be stable as a percentage of net sales. We also manage our working capital using a number of accounts receivable financing programs. See “Off Balance _Sheet Arrangements” below. However, these requirements can fluctuate for a variety of factors, including any significant_ increase in receivables due to longer time periods to collect payment from our customers or a substantial increase in the cost of our raw materials. In addition, Titan Group is party to several supply chain financing arrangements, in which a financial institution fulfils our suppliers’ trade receivables on our behalf and we benefit from extended payment terms. In connection with the Acquisition, we expect that certain of these financing arrangements representing an amount of approximately $124 million as of March 31, 2021 of accounts payable extensions will be discontinued. This may temporarily impact our net working capital and liquidity positions, in which case we may draw down amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility to cover any amounts in excess of internally generated cash flows and cash available on balance sheet. See "Risk Factors — Risks Relating to the Acquisition — _We are exposed to risks related to our supplier financing arrangements which may terminate at completion or shortly following the Acquisition.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Capital expenditures for the three months ended March 31, 2021 and 2020 and the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 amounted to $11 million, $3 million, $33 million (including $2 million growth capital expenditures), $41 million (including $7 million growth capital expenditures), $24 million, respectively. We define capital expenditures as consisting primarily of expenditure on property, plant and equipment. This includes expenditure on new manufacturing plants and expansion of existing plant capacity for new production lines, maintenance capital expenditure comprising expenditures on ----- maintenance of machinery and buildings, improvements of existing plants, and improvements to the health and safety conditions at our facilities. From 2018 to 2020, we invested $98 million in total capital expenditures, of which approximately $9 million was in growth projects. Our historical capital expenditure requirements have been focused on maintaining our existing asset base and improving the health and safety conditions at our facilities. However, there have been several recent growth investments including a new PVC-Free Closure Line, which supports above market growth of PVC Free closures and positions us for highly competitive supply to market. Our estimated capital expenditure budget for the year ended December 31, 2021 is similar to our capital expenditure in the year ended December 31, 2020. We expect that our capital expenditure (including both maintenance and growth capital expenditure) will increase modestly in the near term as we seek to re-allocate capital to margin accretive strategic investments. We have a fully developed capital plan with numerous projects that have payback periods of approximately three years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group utilizes receivables securitization and factoring facilities in the normal course of business as part of managing its cash flows. The factoring programs rely on the creditworthiness of the Group’s customers and not the Group itself. KPS and Titan are in advanced discussions with all of the Company’s factoring counterparties and substantially all have committed to continue their existing programs with Titan on a standalone basis. The Group accounts for transfers under its securitization facilities as sales because the Group sells full title and ownership in the underlying receivables and has met the criteria for control of the receivables to be considered transferred. As of March 31, 2021, March 31, 2020, December 31, 2020, December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2018, the amount outstanding under our securitization arrangements, all of which were non-recourse, was $140 million, $119 million, $129 million, $125 million and $115 million, respectively. ----- The Group accounts for its factoring arrangements as either sales or secured borrowing based on whether it has transferred control over the factored receivables. The Group’s continuing involvement in factored receivables accounted for as sales is limited to servicing the receivables. The Group receives adequate compensation for servicing the receivables and no servicing asset or liability is recorded. As of March 31, 2021, March 31, 2020, December 31, 2020, December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2018, the amount outstanding under our factoring arrangements, almost all of which were non-recourse, was $242 million (of which $7 million was related to recourse factoring arrangements), $225 million (of which $5 million was related to recourse factoring arrangements), $324 million (of which $17 million was related to recourse factoring arrangements), $310 million (of which $14 million was related to recourse factoring arrangements) and $304 million (of which $9 million was related to recourse factoring arrangements), respectively. At December 31, amounts securitized or factored were as follows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Compliance with the Group’s Environmental Protection Policy is mandatory and the responsibility of each employee of the Group. The Group is committed to the protection of human health and the environment and is operating within the increasingly complex laws and regulations of national, state and local environmental agencies or is taking action to achieve compliance with such laws and regulations. Environmental considerations are among the criteria by which the Group evaluates projects, products, processes and purchases. The Group is dedicated to a long-term environmental protection program and has indicated and implemented many pollution prevention programs with an emphasis on source reduction. The Group continues to reduce the amount of metal used in the manufacture of containers through “lightweighting” programs. The Group recycles nearly 100% of scrap aluminum, steel and copper used in its manufacturing processes. Many of the Group’s programs for pollution prevention reduce operating costs and improve operating efficiencies. The potential impact on the Group’s operations of climate change and potential future climate change regulation in the jurisdictions in which the Group operates is highly uncertain. See “Risk Factors––Titan Group is subject to costs and _liabilities related to stringent environmental and health and safety standards.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our financial statements and the accompanying notes contain information that is pertinent to this discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with US GAAP requires our management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses and the related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities. Estimates are evaluated based on available information and experience. Actual results could differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. For a summary of significant accounting policies see note B to the Audited Combined Financial Statements, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Throughout the periods covered by the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements, the Group operated as a part of the Crown Group. Consequently, stand-alone financial statements have not been historically prepared for the Group. The financial statements have been derived from Crown’s historical accounting records as if the Group operated on a stand-alone basis. The financial statements include the historical operations, assets and liabilities of the legal entities and components of legal entities that are considered to comprise the Group’s business. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: During the periods discussed in this Offering Memorandum, the Group presented its financial information in U.S. Dollar. The Group operates in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa and hence currency exchange risk arises from commercial transactions and recognized assets and liabilities. As a result of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements being presented in U.S. Dollar, the results of the Group are also impacted by fluctuations in the U.S. Dollar exchange rate versus the functional currencies of the Group, including the Euro (represents approximately 74% of our revenue), the British Sterling and the Moroccan Dirham. Fluctuations in value of these currencies with respect to the U.S. Dollar may have a significant impact on our financial condition and results of operations. We believe that a strengthening of the U.S. Dollar exchange rate by 1% against all functional currencies from the December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 rate, respectively, would decrease invested capital by approximately $18 million, $17 million and $19 million in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. On a forward going basis, the Business will report in Euro, which is consistent with the primary functional currency of our operating units. We manage foreign currency exposures at the operating unit level. Exposures that cannot be naturally offset within an operating unit may be hedged with derivative financial instruments where possible and cost effective in our judgment. Foreign exchange contracts generally mature within twelve months. The table below provides information in U.S. Dollars as of March 31, 2021 about the Group’s forward currency exchange contracts. The majority of the contracts expire in 2021 and primarily hedge anticipated transactions and unrecognized firm commitments and are recorded at fair value. The contracts with no amounts in the fair value column have a fair value of less than $1 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The main risks to which we are exposed in connection with our operations are raw material costs, interest rate risk and the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates. We limit this exposure through established raw material pass-through practices, as well as programs that include the use of derivative financial instruments, primarily swaps and forwards. Counterparties to these contracts are major financial institutions. These instruments are viewed as risk management tools, involve little complexity and are not used for trading or speculative purposes. The extent to which we use such instruments is dependent upon our access to them in the financial markets and our use of other methods, such as netting exposures for foreign exchange risk and establishing sales arrangements that permit the pass-through to customers of changes in commodity prices and foreign exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we may manage our interest rate risk associated with fluctuations in variable interest rates through interest rate swaps. The use of interest rate swaps and other methods of mitigating interest rate risk may increase overall interest expense.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are modestly exposed to the risk of fluctuations in commodity prices. Our primary raw material, tinplate steel, is not a traded commodity and does not have a commonly accepted index price. Tinplate steel represents approximately 95% of our metal purchases. Despite this dynamic, the nature of our annual tinplate steel pricing negotiations and subsequent pass ----- through pricing strategies to customers for the following year provides a natural hedge as input cost changes are matched to customer price changes. We also purchase aluminum, which represents approximately 5% of our metal purchases. Aluminum is a traded commodity that is regularly quoted on the LME. The risk of changes of the price of aluminum is connected with the common practice of determining the prices in the contracts on the basis of the monthly average sales price of aluminum on the LME. We endeavor to avoid unnecessary risks and limit the impact of threats related to our business to an acceptable level, which is achieved primarily through contracts that pass-through raw material costs to customers and by means of hedging transactions. As of March 31, 2021, the Group had forward commodity contracts to hedge aluminum price fluctuations with a notional value of $12.3 million and a net gain of $2.9 million. The maturities of the commodity contracts closely correlate to the anticipated purchases of those commodities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk arises from cash and deposits with banks and financial institutions, as well as credit exposure to our customers, including outstanding receivables. Credit risk has historically been managed by Crown’s central treasury function, who places excess liquid funds with recognized and reputable financial institutions. The credit ratings of banks and financial institutions are monitored and the risk of default is controlled by limiting the amount of credit exposure to any one bank or institution. It is our policy to extend credit to customers in good standing. Credit risk is managed on an ongoing basis and we periodically assess the financial reliability of customers, taking into account their financial position, past experience and other factors. Provisions are made where deemed necessary and the utilization of credit limits is regularly monitored. We do not expect any significant counterparty to fail to meet its payment obligations towards us. There is no recent history of material non-payment default with any of our major customers. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The global packaging industry is a large, consumer-driven industry with stable growth characteristics. We operate in the metal container sectors and our primary operating regions are Europe, the Middle East and Africa, although we serve the global market with certain of our products. Metal packaging is becoming increasingly attractive to brands as their strength and rigidity allows them to be filled at high speeds and easily transported, while their shelf-stable nature means that refrigeration is not required, thereby resulting in further energy savings in the supply chain. The ability to customize and differentiate products supplied in metal containers, through innovative design, shaping and printing, also appeals to our customers. Metal offers performance and convenience for brands compared to alternatives. It acts as a superior barrier to oxygen and light and is resilient, as it can be durable, tamperproof and fire and temperature resistant. Moreover, it is convenient, and can be light and robust, with portable characteristics and easy open and recloseable solutions. When used in the food market, metal has the advantage of retaining nutritional value, without the requirement for preservatives. From a supply chain perspective, metal packaging allows for efficient transportation and storage and is suited to processing on installed high-speed filling lines and retort processes. Despite competition from other formats and materials, metal cans remain a key food packaging format, owing to their attractive value proposition. The use of metal cans as a food packaging format is expected to have modest but stable growth of 0.6% per annum in the Group’s key markets of Western Europe, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, between 2020 and 2025, principally driven by macroeconomic growth, as forecasted by Smithers. Metal packaging is also increasingly attractive to both brands and end-consumers who are increasingly focused on sustainability. Metal packaging has significant advantages compared to other packaging substrates. Recycling rates for steel and aluminum in Europe are 83% and 76%, respectively, according to Metal Packaging Europe, amongst the highest of any substrate. Moreover, metal’s properties never degrade during use or recycling, as a result, metal is considered a permanent material and plays a critical role in the circular economy. Additionally, all unused material in the production process can be recycled back into production, so no metal scrap created in production goes to waste. Beyond recyclability, metal packaging also aids in sustainability on account of its functionality. Superior barrier properties (as described above) compared to other substrates make metal packaging ideal for food preservation, reducing food waste, increasing the accessibility of healthy foods in an economical manner and providing contamination protection, reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses. Metal has gained increasing traction with brand owners who want to meet their own goals and commitments for sustainability to satisfy their own end-consumers preferences. Companies such as Nestle and Princes Group, both key customers of Titan Group, have stated that they intend to use 100% recyclable or reusable packaging by 2025, and Nestle has announced that they will entirely eliminate the use of ten problematic plastics in their packaging by 2024. Products in the EMEA region’s food can industry are concentrated amongst three food can types: 3-Piece, 2-Piece Drawn and Wall Ironed (“DWI”) and 2-piece Draw Redraw (“DRD”). 3-Piece is a well-established, lower cost steel can with flexible sizes that is used for almost all end-markets, including fish, culinary, pet and nutritional. 2-Piece Drawn Wall Ironed is typically made of steel and has low production costs, high potential for down gauging and fewer can failure modes (with no side seam or end seam) used mostly for seasonal, culinary and pet food end-markets. 2-Piece Draw Redraw is made from steel or aluminum. This is used for shallower cans, offering a wide variety of shapes and high-quality printing. This can mostly serves the fish, culinary and pet food end-markets. Most of the sales in the EMEA region are concentrated in the 3-Piece steel cans, making up 73% of sales, with 2-Piece Aluminum, 2-Piece Steel and other can types making up 11%, 15%, and 1% of can sales in the EMEA market, respectively, as of October 2020, according to Management estimates. Titan Group’s product offering is aligned with the market. 74% of our sales are 3-Piece Steel, and 2-Piece Aluminum and 2-Piece Steel make up 4% and 22% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, respectively. Metal packaging manufacturers hold a critical position in the EMEA food packaging supply chain. Tinplate is the main raw material used in metal packaging production, with approximately 90% of all tinplate produced being used for packaging products according to a leading global consulting firm. This creates an important dynamic between tin manufacturers and can producers. Tinplate manufacturers rely on can manufacturers for a stable source of demand. As EU’s largest buyer of tinplate, consuming 20% of all production in 2019 according to Management estimates, Titan Group represents a critical partner to all major tinplate suppliers in Europe. On the consumers’ side, food producers and can fillers are highly fragmented and are ----- dependent on the quality, safety and availability of cans. The critical position of can manufacturers in the value chain between tinplate producers and food producers and can fillers provides staying power and margin expansion opportunities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The European food cans and ends packaging market is mature and heavily consolidated with the top two players, Titan Group is a clear leader in the food can market, with 39% market share based on 2019 / 2020 EU food cans volume. Collectively, the top two participants in the market hold a combined market share of over 65% based on 2019 / 2020 volume, with no other manufacturer having a market share of greater than 3% according to leading global consulting firm. Other manufacturers consist of mostly regional or local manufacturers, which are limited in scale and footprint to serve customers on a pan-European basis. The European food cans and ends packaging market is relatively insulated from imports given the uneconomical cost of shipping finished metal packaging long distances. In addition, due to the time sensitive nature of customers’ requirements, customers prefer shorter supply chains, benefiting manufacturers that are located nearby to customers. Furthermore, new challengers in the markets face significant obstacles in the form of high barriers to entry for numerous reasons. Sizable capital requirements are needed to add capacity, particularly in the front-end of operations such as coil cutting, printing and lacquering. Additionally, new entrants find economic benefits of adding capacity limited, especially in mature markets with entrenched customers. There are also rigorous qualification requirements demanded by sensitive food end-markets. Additionally, many customers have filling lines which are tuned to work with certain suppliers, resulting in high switching costs and creating a barrier for new entrants in the market. Lastly, inherent strengths of the metal substrate, including rigidity and corrosion resistance, provides tinplate with a degree of protection against substitution from other substrates like aluminum or plastics.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Closures, aerosols and promotional packaging markets represent smaller subsectors of the metal packaging industry. Metal vacuum closures exist in a variety of shapes, sizes and specifications and help provide easy-open convenience and visual appeal for packaging across various substrates. Aerosols come in various diameters and finishings, serving mainly the personal care, food and household end-markets. Promotional and premium containers come in numerous lid and closure variations, servicing mostly the biscuits, powders, confectionery and syrup end-markets. Within Closures, Titan Group holds the number two market position with over 25% market share in Europe as of October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary closures competitors include Silgan, Technocap and Massilly. ----- Titan Group also holds the number two market position in Aerosol packaging, with over 10% market share in Europe as of October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary competitors in aerosols include Colep, Sarten, Staehle and Trivium amongst numerous smaller, regional manufacturers. The Group offers tinplate 3-piece aerosol cans for personal care, food, household and industrial markets. The Group is also the number one European player for promotional packaging, with over 20% market share in Europe as of October 2020 according to Management estimates. The Group’s primary competitors for this product segment include Envases Europe, Klann, smaller, regional manufacturers and various international competitors. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The food can packaging market, which is the second largest metal can packaging category globally after beverage cans according to Wall Street equity research, has historically experienced stable demand throughout economic cycles. In Europe, the food cans industry sold approximately 26.7 billion units in 2020 according to a leading global consulting firm, representing a CAGR of 0.2% since 2015. Specifically, many key food end-markets including fruit & vegetables, shelf stable fish, culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula have shown resilience over time. According to a leading global consulting firm analysis representing trends for European food cans volume sold, market growth of fruits & vegetables, culinary and pet food have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1% between 2015 and 2020. Shelf stable fish, culinary and pet food are expected to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1% between 2020 and 2024, with infant nutrition expected to grow by a CAGR of 1.0% from 2020 to 2023. Fruits & vegetables are expected to decline by a CAGR of 1.4% between 2020 and 2024. Shelf stable foods represent a consumer diet staple across most cultures and geographies. Metal cans currently represent the best barrier material and provides over two years of shelf-life, which is critical for managing seasonal harvest cycles. This shelf-life helps maintain the availability of the underlying food product for consumers, should there be a poor harvest of the relevant item during this two-year period. In 2020, shelf stable foods experienced additional growth attributed to an increase in at-home meal consumption and evolving consumer preferences due to the COVID-19 pandemic, although this benefit was somewhat offset by reduced demand for food cans in food service applications. A majority of the recent demand increases and underlying trends are forecast to persist according to a leading global consulting firm, with sustainability trends expected to provide favorable long-term market tailwinds. These developments are supported by recent innovations into convenient, single-serve packaging offerings. Pet food and infant nutrition represent particular areas of potential growth. The dog and cat populations in Europe continue to increase and pet owners have demonstrated a willingness to spend considerable sums on their pets. Furthermore, Europe exports a significant amount of infant nutrition products and over the past 10 years over $1 billion has been invested in Europe for filling infant nutrition into metal cans.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of our results of operations and financial condition as of and for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, as derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements and as of and for the three-months periods ended March 31, 2020 and 2021 as derived from the Unaudited Interim Condensed Combined Financial Statements. It covers periods prior to the consummation of the Acquisition; accordingly, the discussion and analysis of historical periods does not reflect the significant impact that the Transactions will have on us. Certain monetary amounts, percentages and other figures included in this Offering Memorandum have been subject to rounding adjustments. Accordingly, figures shown as totals in certain tables may not be the arithmetic aggregation of the figures that precede them, and figures expressed as percentages in the text may not total 100% or, as applicable, when aggregated may not be the arithmetic aggregation of the percentages that precede them. Unless the context indicates otherwise, in this section references to “we,” “us,” “our,” or the “Group,” refer, to the Titan Group comprising the Business. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Summary Financial Information and Other Data” and “Selected Financial Information” of this Offering Memorandum. For the preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Combined Financial Statements it was necessary to make assumptions and estimates.
