Accordingly, the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Combined Financial Statements do not necessarily reflect the financial position and performance that would have been presented if the Titan Group had already existed as an independent group during the periods presented herein. As a result, the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Combined Financial Statements are not necessarily indicative of the future developments of the business. The statements in this discussion regarding industry outlook, our expectations regarding our future performance, liquidity and capital resources and other non-historical statements in this discussion are forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties, including, but not limited to, the risks and uncertainties described in the “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements” sections of this Offering Memorandum. Our actual results may differ materially from those contained in or implied by any forward-looking statements._

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: We are a European leader in the design, manufacture and sale of metal packaging solutions, with number one or number two market positions across our product groups in the countries we operate in. We are the clear market leader in the 26.7-billion-unit European market for metal food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. As the largest European manufacturer of metal food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel (based on our estimated consumption of approximately 20% of total European tinplate production), our business is a critical asset in the European food supply chain. We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe. Our product portfolio consists predominantly of food packaging, with approximately 95% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020 going to food related end markets. Our products are used by hundreds of millions of consumers on a daily basis across Europe, the Middle East and Africa. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Our products are used to package food in a diverse array of end-markets, including fruits and vegetables, tomatoes, fish, pet food, culinary, infant nutrition and dairy. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 3. Diverse, blue-chip customer base with longstanding, contractual relationships
Subsubsection Text: We supply over 1,000 customers across a range of resilient product categories and end markets. No single customer represented more than 8% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with our top 10 customers representing 32% of sales for the same period. Our customers include blue-chip, global food and consumer businesses including Abbott, Bonduelle, Danone, Nestle and Unilever, large national and regional food companies, as well as many smaller and independent fisheries and farmers. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers on average for over 25 years. We are the sole or main supplier for several of our top customers. We believe that the quality of our products, our track record of providing reliable supply proven over decades and the significant costs to customers involved in switching manufacturers creates customer stickiness. Before a manufacturing plant or line can begin manufacturing new can SKUs for a customer, its products typically must be qualified through a process that can take several months to over a year. In addition, can manufacturers may face downtime on their lines when running new SKUs, thereby impacting customers’ security and reliability of supply. Customers who decide to change manufacturers also typically lose the benefit of volume rebates from former suppliers and face uncertainty regarding the stability, reliability and quality of their new partners. Customers praise our technological know-how, understanding of their requirements and ability to produce and deliver large volumes of specialty food cans consistently on time and in full. Our customers incur high costs if their packaging is not delivered when required. As an example, tomatoes must be sealed in their packaging within six hours of being picked to ensure their freshness, often requiring our manufacturing facilities to ship dozens of truckloads of food cans per day in a continuous rotation to certain customer facilities during harvest season. We are recognized as an industry leader in product development and deliver solutions that offer greater consumer convenience and functionality in response to market demands. Can fillers require producers who can satisfy their branding, quality and safety needs. We believe we consistently satisfy these needs and enable our customers to differentiate their brands through packaging and address changing safety requirements ahead of time.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 4. Sustainability- and consumer-driven tailwinds benefit metal packaging
Subsubsection Text: Our metal packaging products are favorably positioned to benefit from the increase in demand for sustainable packaging given their infinitely recyclable nature. Greater environmental consciousness and strong sustainability trends are expected to support an increased preference for metal packaging over the long-term. End consumers increasingly view sustainability as a key purchasing criteria and seek out more environmentally friendly packaging. Food producers – our customers – are aggressively responding to this demand. For example, several major food conglomerates have announced that they aim to sell mostly recyclable or reusable materials by 2025. These trends are further reinforced by regulatory developments. For example, the EU circular economy plan adopted in 2020 has a clear focus on recyclable packaging, which is likely to put pressure on plastic in favor of other packaging materials. Metal packaging provides excellent options for the sustainability initiatives of companies and brands, since metal properties do not degrade during use or recycling. Consumers already recognize metal packaging as a highly recyclable substrate, evidenced by recycling rates of over 80% for steel and 75% for aluminum in Europe, and food brands increasingly want to position themselves as environmentally friendly. As a further sustainability benefit, metal packaging’s superior barrier properties make it ideal for food preservation, which reduces food waste. Metal packaging increases the accessibility of healthy foods in an economical manner and provides contamination protection, thereby reducing the prevalence of food-borne illnesses. ----- Within the metal packaging industry, we are a European leader in sustainability awareness as a Co-Founder of the Metal Packaging Europe Association and an active participant in other major sustainability focused associations, which serve as conduits for sustainability reform at the regulatory and legislative level.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 5. Attractive financial profile with flexible cost structure and ability to generate consistent free cash flow
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track-record of robust free cash flow generation and cash conversion as a result of our flexible cost structure and resilient cash flows. We generated average annual free cash flow of $239 million and an average cash conversion rate of approximately 88% from 2018 to 2020. Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and negotiated pass-through mechanisms, providing us with consistent historical cash flows and supporting our margins. We have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, over 97% of Titan Group’s pricing for 2021 was already agreed. We estimate that approximately 87% of our cost base is fully- or semi-variable, consisting mostly of material costs, labor costs, freight, energy, which represented 61%, 15%, 5% and 3%, respectively, of our total costs for the year ended December 31, 2020 in addition to other consumables. The semi-variable characteristics of our labor costs come from our ability to reduce our labor costs through the use of seasonal and temporary employees. Our variable cost structure allows us to quickly adapt our production capacity to harvest cycles, which can result in modest volume fluctuations from year to year. Our cash flow stability is bolstered by the non-cyclical end-markets we serve, our ability to pass-through raw material prices changes, our long-term customer relationships with contracted volumes, and customer stickiness. Our modest capital expenditure requirements and well-managed, disciplined approach to working capital further strengthen our free cash flow conversion. We believe our free cash flow profile will enable us to reduce leverage through debt repayment over time.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Title: 6. Experienced management team supported by a best-in-class financial sponsor
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from a talented management team with deep roots in the business and decades of experience. Our management team has a strong track-record of value creation in the consumer packaging industry and has an average 30 years of service in the industry. Our management team has been involved in the preparation of our transition from being a part of Crown to operating as a stand-alone business, including the development of our stand-alone strategy. We have also moved to reinforce the team in its new existence as a stand-alone company by announcing the appointment of Tomás López as Chief Executive Officer. Mr López will bring experience and a track-record of success in managing Mivisa before it was acquired by Crown. See also “Management.” KPS Capital Partners (“KPS”) has a strong track-record of realising improvements in manufacturing companies and over two decades of constructive investing in highly complex corporate carve-outs on a global basis. KPS creates value for its investors by working constructively with talented management teams to make businesses better, and generates investment returns by structurally improving the strategic position, competitiveness and profitability of its portfolio companies, rather than primarily relying on financial leverage. KPS will support management and leverage its core operational improvement expertise. Furthermore, Crown will retain a 20% equity stake in the stand-alone company, validating its belief in the potential of the business and allow for a smooth transition of the business to an independent company.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Note: For the year ended December 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: 1. According to leading global consulting firm 2. According to Management estimates We sell our products in more than 90 countries with France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany representing 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of our sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and other ----- geographies making up the remaining 41% of sales in the same period. Sales to our top 10 customers represented just 32% of our total sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. We benefit from long-standing relationships with our customers, having worked with our top 10 customers for an average of over 25 years. Our business is significantly insulated from raw material price fluctuation through a combination of formulaic and negotiated raw material pass-through mechanisms, providing us with margin stability and consistent historical cash flows. We have demonstrated our ability to pass through fluctuations in the prices of our raw material inputs over the long term. Moreover, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Titan Group’s pass-through was on track for full recovery of raw material price increases in 2021. Based on Management estimates, the vast majority of sales are covered by at least annual contracts, with up to 40% of total sales secured on multi-year contracts. Our customer contracts provide sales volume visibility, as many contracts stipulate a guaranteed percentage of total customer orders for the term of the contract. We operate 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) in 17 countries in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which enhance our access to customer end-markets and support local demand. Our manufacturing scale is complemented by our services and customer support capabilities including over 20 technical services locations, seven dedicated product design studios, four dedicated laboratory testing facilities and a world-class research and development facility that have put us at the forefront of the European tinplate packaging industry. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had net sales of $2,241 million, $2,138 million and $2,227 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of $303 million, $247 million and $267 million, respectively. Our net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were $2,297 million and $317 million, respectively, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. These amounts translate, for convenience purposes only, for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, to net sales of €1,897 million, €1,910 million and €1,951 million, respectively, and Adjusted EBITDA of €256 million, €221 million and €234 million, respectively, and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, to net sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA of €1,974 million and €272 million, respectively. Metal cans represent the best barrier material and provide a shelf life of over two years while still retaining the freshness of the food being packaged. In addition, metal food cans provide a host of other benefits to our customers, including i) allowing for fast filling speeds with limited loss, ii) having high strength and allowing for ease of handling and iii) being resistant to corrosion, thereby allowing for high-acid contents (e.g., tomatoes). These qualities make our products highly costeffective solutions for our customers and limit the threat of substitution from other substrates. The stability of our end-markets is evidenced by their historical and forecast growth rates. According to a leading global consulting firm market growth for the packaging of shelf stable vegetables, culinary products, infant nutrition products and shelf stable fish in Europe have each fluctuated by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2015 and 2020, and are expected to fluctuate by CAGRs of less than +/-1.5% between 2020 and 2024. Furthermore, between 2015 and 2020 the food can volumes sold in Iberia grew by a CAGR of 2% and in our other key markets of France, Italy, the UK and Germany food can volumes fluctuated by a CAGR of less than +/-1.5% over this period.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: 1. Longstanding European market leader and critical asset in the European food packaging supply chain
Subsubsection Text: We are the clear leader in the European market for food cans and ends, holding the number one market position with an approximate 39% market share based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. Sales of metal food cans and ends represented 85% of our total revenue in this period. We also believe that we hold the number one or number two market position in Europe across the other product categories we serve, namely metal closures, aerosol cans and promotional containers with market shares of approximately 28%, 12% and 24%, respectively, measured by volume for the year ended December 31, 2020. We have been in the European market for over 200 years and have a reputation with customers for providing the highest quality products and superior service. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we produced approximately 12 billion food cans, approximately 24 billion ends, approximately 5.3 billion metal closures, approximately 581 million aerosol cans and approximately 134 million metal promotional packaging containers. Including intermediate precursor products, our manufacturing assets produce 500 million products per day on average. We have a well-established manufacturing presence with 44 strategically located manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period) across 17 countries enhancing access to customers, end markets, local demand and suppliers. We operate 34 food cans & ends manufacturing facilities (in addition to the Braunstone site, which will be transferred at the end of the transition period), five closures manufacturing facilities, three aerosol manufacturing facilities and three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities. We have a well-invested asset base supported by in-house research and development expertise. We believe the investment required to replicate our facility footprint, in addition to the know-how of operating canmaking assets that we developed over our history create high barriers to entry. The European market for food cans and ends is mature and highly consolidated with the top two players, ourselves and our primary competitor, holding a combined market share of over 65% based on volume in the year ended December 31, 2020. The third largest manufacturer has a market share of 3%. Other competitors consist of mostly regional or local manufacturers, who lack the ability to serve larger food customers at scale or are limited in their ability to serve customers across multiple geographies. The European food cans and ends market is relatively insulated from import competition given the high cost of shipping metal packaging long distances and the short lead times customers demand. Due to the significance of transportation costs in the food can industry, our regional production capabilities support expedient and cost-efficient transportation to local customers. Furthermore, there are high barriers to entry due to sizeable capital requirements needed to ----- add capacity, rigorous qualification requirements demanded by customers, and heightened scrutiny with respect to safety requirements as a result of serving sensitive food end-markets. We hold a critical position in the European food packaging supply chain as the largest European manufacturer of metal food cans and ends and the largest European buyer of tinplate steel. Our business is the key link between tinplate steel, a commodity raw material that we purchase and convert to finished packaging for our large and fragmented, primarily European, customer base of food manufacturers. Can producers are the largest consumers of tinplate steel in Europe, with approximately 90% of tinplate steel in Europe being used in packaging, of which 40 to 50% is for food cans and 10 to 15% is for each of beverages, general line, aerosols and closures. Moreover, the market is largely stable with no significant shifts expected. We are Europe’s largest buyer of tinplate, consuming approximately 20% of all tinplate production in Europe in 2020 according to Management estimates. Tinplate steel suppliers rely on us for a stable source of demand, and our position as the largest consumer of tinplate steel makes us a critical partner to all of the major suppliers of tinplate steel in the European market. Our over 1,000 customers rely on us as Europe’s largest supplier of food cans and ends. Because of our scale, we are often the only supplier that can serve high volume customers on a pan-European basis. Our customers depend on our supply to go to market and rely on our packaging to ensure their products reach store shelves. We provide their products with the benefit of a long shelf life that metal food cans offer. Our packaging is an important part of our customers’ brands, and we work closely with our customers to develop designs that ensure their products are attractive to end-consumers at points of sale.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: 2. Diverse, stable revenue mix with exposure to a range of non-cyclical, food-related end markets
Subsubsection Text: We sell essential food packaging products into a highly diverse mix of geographies, customers and end-markets, which supports revenue stability and resilience. Our products serve over 90 countries consisting of both sales into mature, developed countries and higher growth, developing countries. No single country represented more than 15% of our sales in the year ended December 31, 2020, with the largest contributors being France, Spain, the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany at 15%, 14%, 12%, 11% and 7% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Our product portfolio consists 95% of food packaging, which has historically experienced stable demand throughout economic cycles. We serve numerous food-related end-markets, including shelf-stable fruit and vegetables, shelf-stable fish, culinary (such as baked beans), pet food and infant formula, which represented 24%, 18%, 11%, 8% and 8% of sales, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. Each of our end-markets is driven by fundamental demand drivers, such as population growth, eating at home trends, urbanization, and a growing global middle class, that are stable and largely uncorrelated with broader macroeconomic cycles, and not subject to significant innovation threats. -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Business has numerous growth opportunities arising from favorable consumption trends, such as a greater focus on convenience, growth in single serve packaging, increasing premiumization and higher focus on sustainability. Operating as a stand-alone entity, we will have greater flexibility to pursue opportunities that were not previously considered or prioritized while integrated within the wider Crown business. In addition, we will have the benefit of a steady capital expenditure program that is focused on our business, allowing us to pursue multi-year growth projects which we were unable to pursue under prior ownership. End-markets such as infant nutrition and wet petfood have volume growth opportunities at attractive margins that we believe we can capture by employing our capabilities and expertise developed in other end-markets. Our metal cans are well-positioned to benefit from these growth opportunities in light of their favorable barrier properties and the premium perception and convenience that our products offer. In addition, we are focused on growing our share and penetration in key emerging markets such as Eastern Europe and Africa, where our existing customers are establishing footprints that we can readily support with existing technologies and know-how.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Tinplate steel makes up for more than 80% of our raw materials spend and represented 48% of our cost of products sold in the year ended December 31, 2020. We believe our market position enables us to optimize sourcing and pricing for our tinplate steel purchases and provides further opportunities for margin expansion. While the Business under Crown’s ownership mainly focused on ensuring stability of supply and favorable working capital arrangements, as a stand-alone business we will have the opportunity to manage supply arrangements in support of better margins, including through utilizing a greater share of raw materials from low cost countries. We have developed optimization initiatives to realize the most favorable pricing with suppliers for the highest quality tinplate with the shortest supply chain lead times. There is potential for additional cost savings opportunities in the form of reduced spend on logistics, raw material specification complexity reductions, indirect cost savings and contract structure improvements. We believe there is an opportunity to purchase higher volume of fewer SKUs, and also consolidate production of precursor products into fewer facilities, thereby reducing the number of facilities receiving raw material shipments and to improve the structure of certain of our contracts. In addition, we believe there are opportunities to optimize indirect and other materials procurement through targeted sourcing initiatives. In the three months ended March 31, 2021, Titan Group already realized the benefit of improved procurement practices and commercial efforts, leading to expanding margins for this period.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: We expect to realize further efficiencies by improving the asset utilization and productivity of our manufacturing footprint. We intend to employ targeted capital expenditures focused on modernizing the equipment used at several of our key facilities with a goal of increasing the capacity of those facilities and allowing more efficient and cost-effective production while reducing the number of facilities in our network. Our Business grew substantially following the acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, however, we did not fully integrate the Mivisa and legacy manufacturing footprints and did not achieve the margin targets or synergies forecast at the time. We believe that there are certain manufacturing function overlaps and duplications as a result of the acquisition and our organic growth. We intend to replicate the “hub and spoke” operating model, used successfully by Mivisa, whereby certain functions that can easily and cost-effectively be transported are completed at lower cost plants to improve and optimize asset utilization. For example, we believe that the manufacturing of ends and certain upstream functions such as metal processing and coating can be consolidated into facilities that specialize in production of those precursor products. Such products would then be transported to existing can finishing or assembly plants that are located close to our customers and have a lean operating footprint. This approach was successfully developed at Mivisa, which operated the largest ends production facility in the world in Murcia, Spain, producing more than 9 billion ends annually and serviced nearly its entire network using this plant and also serviced a significant export business of ends. We intend to replicate this model across the Group’s existing manufacturing footprint.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: 4. Commercial Excellence and Continuous Improvement Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: In addition to revenue improvement and market share capture, our strategy also has a strong focus on delivering further cost savings and unlocking further margin improvement potential. We plan to develop a continuous improvement culture and ----- invest in training across the entire business. KPS and Management have conducted a comprehensive and granular review of our operating model. We believe that as a stand-alone business, we will be able to realize these cost savings and margin expansions based on KPS’ proven track record in realising improvements in manufacturing businesses. We have identified a number of commercial excellence and continuous improvement priorities, including (i) more focused deployment of capital expenditures, (ii) quality management in the form of manufacturing and operational excellence initiatives; (iii) maintenance and repair optimization, (iv) using a local sales force to improve engagement between our sales and operations teams and (v) a focus on customer service, innovation and responsiveness initiatives. As a stand-alone business focused on the manufacturing of food cans and ends, we will be more readily able to pursue these opportunities rather than having to compete with the other capital priorities of our former owner. Our planned capital projects include investments focused on asset productivity, such as tooling upgrades to multi-die presses and high speed printing and coating lines capable of delivering up to 300% improvements in productivity. Our planned capital projects typically have a payback of approximately two to three years. We also believe there is an opportunity to improve the effectiveness of our commercial function by streamlining our financial reporting structure, providing greater visibility to our local sales teams and enabling them to optimize the margin profile of products they are selling. We believe our customers derive significant value from our product offering and we intend to capture additional margin for the superior service and capabilities that we offer.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Our strong cash flow generation has historically been utilized in support of broader goals within the larger Crown organization. We have a unique position in the European food supply chain as the largest manufacturer of food cans and ends in Europe and we believe that we are the largest buyer of tinplate steel in Europe. We believe that, despite our market position, our historic margins have lagged those of key competitors and our own potential as a result of the lack of focus on our business under our prior owners. Under Crown’s ownership, the business has mainly focused on volumes and cash generation to support Crown’s other businesses, which presents a significant opportunity for margin improvement. From 2017 to 2020, Titan Group represented approximately 20% of Crown’s sales but only 8% of its capital expenditures. ----- As a stand-alone business, we aim to reorient the business towards growth and margin improvement. Capitalizing on the above strengths as a stand-alone business, we believe we have numerous levers to create additional value, grow volumes, improve profitability and generate cash flows.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: We have been in the industry for more than 200 years and have an established reputation for the highest quality products and exceptional customer service. From the founding of our predecessor business in 1799 to our acquisition by Crown in 1996 and our acquisition of Mivisa in 2014, our business has shown itself to be a leader in European metal packaging time and time again. Following the Transactions, we will become a leading stand-alone business in Europe. The businesses, operations, assets and liabilities comprising the Titan Group are currently being operated as part and under the umbrella of the global Crown Group. On April 8, 2021, Bidco and Crown entered into the Acquisition Agreement pursuant to which Crown has agreed to sell the Titan Group to Bidco pursuant to the terms and conditions set forth in the Acquisition Agreement. Upon completion of the Acquisition, Bidco and its direct and indirect shareholders will become the majority shareholder of our business (with Crown retaining a 20% ownership stake) and Titan Group will operate on a standalone basis, see also “Risk Factors––We have no operating history as a standalone company.” The proceeds of the Offering will, upon satisfaction of the conditions to release from the Escrow Account, be used to fund part of the cash portion of the consideration due to Crown under the Acquisition Agreement. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, neither the Issuer, nor Bidco has any material assets or liabilities nor have the Issuer or Bidco engaged in any activities other than those related to their incorporation and registration and the Acquisition. Unless otherwise required by the context, this Offering Memorandum presents our business and operations and other information as if the Acquisition has occurred.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group manufactures a variety of food cans, including two-piece and three-piece cans in numerous shapes and sizes, which are being sold to global and regional food producers, independent fisheries and farmers. Some of Titan Group’s food cans and ends customers include Abbot Laboratories, Bonduelle, C&D Foods, Jealsa, Nestle and Princes Group, among others. Technologies used to produce food cans include three-piece welded, two-piece drawn and wall-ironed and two-piece drawn and redrawn. ----- The Group also manufactures easy open, vacuum and conventional ends for a variety of heat-processed and dry food products including fruits and vegetables, meat and seafood, soups, ready-made meals, infant formula, coffee and pet food. The Group owns several trademarks and offers a series of can ends, including its Easylift™ full aperture steel food can ends, and PeelSeam™ and PeelFit™, flexible aluminum foil laminated food can ends to its customers. We serve our food cans and ends customers from our 34 metal can and ends manufacturing facilities located in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group also offers a wide variety of metal vacuum closures and sealing equipment solutions to leading global and regional food producers including Andros Foods, Danone, Greencore, Neerlands Glorie, Orkla and Unilever, among others. ----- The Group offers expertise in closure design and decoration, ranging from quality printing of the closure in up to nine colors, to inside-the-cap printing, which offers customers new promotional possibilities and better product protection through our trademark Orbit™. We serve our closures customers from five manufacturing facilities located in Europe.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s customers for aerosol cans and ends include manufacturers of personal care, food, household and industrial products, including Friesland Campina, SC Johnson, Unilever and WD-40, among others. The Group offers its customers a broad range of products including multiple sizes and finishing schemes as well as a full array of design, technical and market support services. We serve our aerosols customers from three aerosols manufacturing facilities located in Europe. -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s promotional packaging business is primarily located in Europe. The Group produces a wide variety of promotional and premium containers with numerous lid and closure variations. The Group offers its customers an extensive portfolio of packaging designs and printing capabilities that help differentiate its products (and those of its customers) in the marketplace. The Group was awarded the Can of the Year award in 2020 by The Canmaker magazine for packaging it designed and produced for Fishers Gin, which serves as an example of the Group’s leading capabilities in promotional packaging. Some of the Group’s promotional packaging customers include Ferrero, Britvic Nestle and Mondelez, primarily for promotional activities. We serve our promotional packaging customers from three promotional packaging manufacturing facilities located in the United Kingdom.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: We supply total packaging solutions, including metal cans, ends and closures, tinplate aerosol cans and promotional premium metal containers while working closely with customers, retailers and glass and plastic container manufacturers to develop innovative closure solutions and meet customer requirements. The Group’s commitment to innovation has led to developments in packaging materials, surface finishes, can shaping, lithography, filling, retorting, sealing and opening techniques and environmental performance. Through our manufacturing network of 44 facilities in Europe, the Middle East and Africa (and the Braunstone UK facility, which Crown will transfer to the Titan Group post-closing), we serve our customers in over 92 countries.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Titan Group’s customers qualify suppliers on the basis of their ability to provide consistent service with strong quality performance, innovative designs and technologies in a cost-effective manner. ----- The Group markets and sells products to customers through its own sales and marketing staff. Contracts with large customers are generally centrally negotiated, but products are ordered through and distributed directly by the Group’s local facilities. The Group’s facilities are generally located in proximity to their respective major customers, particularly for food cans, as these products do not ship cost-effectively across long distances. The Group works closely with customers to develop new business and to extend the terms and scope of its existing contracts. Many customers provide the Group with quarterly or annual estimates of product requirements along with related quantities pursuant to which periodic commitments are given. Such estimates assist the Group in managing production and controlling use of working capital. The Group schedules its production to meet customer requirements. Because the production time for the Group’s products is short, any backlog of customer orders in relation to overall sales is not significant.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The food packaging business is seasonal with the first quarter tending to be the slowest period as the autumn packing period in the Northern Hemisphere has ended and new crops are not yet planted. The industry generally enters its busiest period in the third quarter when the majority of fruits and vegetables are harvested. Due to this seasonality, inventory levels increase in the first half of the year to meet peak demand in the second and third quarters. Weather represents a substantial uncertainty in the yield of food products and is a major factor in determining the demand for food cans in any given year. See also “Risk _Factors––Titan Group's business is seasonal and adverse weather conditions could reduce Titan Group's net sales.”_ The Group’s other businesses primarily include aerosol and specialty packaging and can making equipment, which tend not to be as significantly affected by seasonal variations.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Most of the Group’s products are sold in highly competitive markets, primarily based on price, quality, service and performance. The Business competes with other packaging manufacturers as well as with fillers, food processors and packers, who, to a limited extent, manufacture containers for their own use and for sale to others. The Group’s competitors include, but are not limited to, Massilly, Silgan Holdings, Trivium, Auxiliar, DomIberia, Glud Marstrand and Sarten.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s customers consist of global and regional food producers, consumer products manufacturers and marketers and independent fisheries and farmers. The Group was the sole or primary supplier for its top ten customers with whom it had an average relationship of over 25 years. The Group’s top ten customers represented in the aggregate approximately 32% of its net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020. In each of the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, no one customer accounted for more than 7% of the Group’s net sales. See also “Risk Factors––The loss of a major _customer and/or customer consolidation could reduce Titan Group's net sales and profitability.” The contracts with our_ customers generally provide for the pass-through of metal price fluctuations. In addition, multiyear relationships allow both parties to work together to streamline the product, service and supply process, potentially leading to cost reductions and improvements in product and service, with benefits arising to both parties. Wherever possible, we seek to enter into multi-year supply agreements with our customers. See also below under “––Research and Development.” Titan’s product offerings are complemented by topline services and customer support. Titan Group has over 20 customer technical services locations, 7 dedicated product design studios and 4 dedicated laboratory testing facilities.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s principal Research, Development & Engineering (“RD&E”) Center is located in Wantage, England. The Group utilizes its centralized RD&E capabilities to advance and deliver technologies for its international packaging activities that (1) promote development of value-added metal packaging systems for its customers, (2) design cost-efficient manufacturing processes, systems and materials that further the sustainability of metal packaging, (3) provide continuous quality and/or production efficiency improvements in its manufacturing facilities, (4) advance customer and vendor relationships, and (5) provide value-added engineering services and technical support. These capabilities facilitate (1) the identification of new and/or expanded market opportunities by working directly with customers to develop new packaging products or enhance existing packaging products through the application of new technologies that better differentiate our customers’ products in the retail environment (for example, the creation of new packaging shapes or novel decoration methods) and/or the incorporation of consumer-valued features (for example, improved openability and ease of use) and (2) the reduction of manufacturing costs by reducing the material content of the Group‘s products (while retaining necessary performance characteristics), reducing spoilage, and increasing operating efficiencies in our manufacturing facilities. ----- The Group maintains a substantial portfolio of patents and other intellectual property (IP) in the field of metal packaging ends and closures, in particular, and seeks strategic partnerships to extend its IP in existing and emerging markets. The Group spent $6.9 million, $6.8 million and $7.3 million in the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively in its centralized RD&E activities. Certain of these activities are expected to improve and expand the Group’s product lines in the future. These expenditures include projects within the Group’s RD&E facilities to improve manufacturing efficiencies, reduce unit costs, and develop new and improved value-added packaging systems. These expenditures do not include related product and process developments occurring within the Group’s decentralized business units.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group uses various raw materials, primarily tinplate steel, in its manufacturing operations. In general, these raw materials are purchased in highly competitive, price-sensitive markets which have historically exhibited price and demand cyclicality. These and other materials used in the manufacturing process have historically been available in adequate supply from multiple sources. Generally, the Group’s principal raw materials are obtained from the major suppliers in the regions in which it operates plants. Titan Group estimates that it sources approximately 75-80% of its tinplate from the largest three European suppliers and up to 25% from European challengers and imports from outside Europe, including China, Japan, Turkey and South Korea. Some plants in less developed countries, which do not have local mills, obtain raw materials from nearby, more developed countries. The Group has agreements for what it considers adequate supplies of raw materials. However, sufficient quantities may not be available in the future due to, among other things, shortages due to excessive demand, weather or other factors, including disruptions in supply caused by raw material transportation or production delays. From time to time, some of the raw materials have been in short supply but, to date, these shortages have not had a significant impact on the Group’s operations. See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's financial results could be materially adversely affected if Titan Group is not able to _secure sufficient quantities of raw materials or if the price of raw materials or energy rises and Titan Group cannot increase the price of its products.”_ In the year ended December 31, 2020, consumption of tinplate steel represented approximately 48% of consolidated cost of products sold, excluding depreciation and amortization. Due to the significance of tinplate steel to overall cost of products sold, raw material efficiency is a critical cost component of the products manufactured. Supplier consolidations, changes in ownership, government regulations, political unrest and increased demand for raw materials in the packaging and other industries, among other risk factors, provide uncertainty as to the availability of and the level of prices at which the Group might be able to source such raw materials in the future. Moreover, the price of raw materials can be subject to significant volatility. The Group’s raw material supply contracts vary as to terms and duration, with tinplate steel contracts typically one year in duration with fixed prices for the year. The Group generally attempts to mitigate its steel price risk by matching its purchase obligations with its sales agreements; however, there can be no assurance that the Group will be able to fully mitigate that risk. See also “Risk Factors––Titan Group's financial results could be materially adversely affected if Titan Group is not _able to secure sufficient quantities of raw materials or if the price of raw materials or energy rises and Titan Group cannot increase the price of its products.”_ There can be no assurance that the Group will be able to fully recover from its customers the impact of raw material price increases or that the use of derivative instruments will effectively manage the Group’s exposure to price volatility. In addition, if the Group is unable to purchase raw materials, particularly tinplate steel, for a significant period of time, its operations would be disrupted and if the Group were unable to fully recover the higher cost of those raw materials, its financial results may be adversely affected. The Group continues to monitor this situation and the effect on its operations. As a result of continuing international supply and demand pressures, other commodity-related costs affecting the Group’s business may increase as well, including natural gas, electricity and freight-related costs. The Group will attempt to increase prices on its products accordingly in order to recover these costs. In response to the volatility of raw material prices, ongoing productivity and cost reduction efforts in recent years have focused on improving raw material cost management. The Group’s manufacturing facilities are dependent, in varying degrees, upon the availability of water and processed energy, such as natural gas and electricity. Certain of these may become difficult or impossible to obtain on acceptable terms due to external factors which could increase the Group’s costs or interrupt its business. -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: Sustainability and Environmental, Health and Safety Matters
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s Credit Facilities Agreement is currently planned to incorporate a sustainability ratchet, whereby the margin thereunder is subject to adjustment based on the Group’s performance measured against certain key performance indicators, currently envisioned to be centered around greenhouse gas emissions, product lifecycle management and air quality. The Group’s operations are subject to numerous laws and regulations governing the protection of the environment, including notably those relating to treatment, storage and disposal of waste, the use of chemicals in the Group’s products and manufacturing process, discharges into water, emissions into the atmosphere, remediation of soil and groundwater contamination and protection of employee health and safety. Future regulations may impose stricter environmental requirements on the packaging industry and may require additional capital investment. Anticipated future restrictions in some jurisdictions on the use of certain coatings may require the Group to employ additional control equipment or process modifications. The Group has a Corporate Sustainability Policy and a Corporate Environmental Protection Policy. Environmental awareness is a key component of sustainability. Environmental considerations are among the criteria by which the Group evaluates projects, products, processes and purchases. The Group is committed to continuous improvement in product design and manufacturing practices to provide the best outcome for the human and natural environment, both now and in the future. The Group has annual objectives with an emphasis on spoilage reduction, resource realignments, efficiency improvements and labor savings. By reducing the per-unit amount of raw materials used in manufacturing its products through “lightweighting”, the Group can significantly reduce the amount of energy, water and other resources and associated emissions necessary to manufacture metal containers. The Group aims to continue that process of improvement in its manufacturing process through investment in machinery upgrades with state-of-the-art, energy-efficient technologies and standardization programs focused on material and efficiency savings to assure that consumers and the environment are best served through the use of metal packaging. The Group is also committed to providing a safe work environment for its employees through programs that emphasize safety awareness and the elimination of injuries and incidents. The Group had no significant incidents in 2020.There can be no assurance that current or future environmental laws or liabilities will not have a material effect on the Group’s financial condition, liquidity or results of operations. Discussion of the Group’s environmental matters is contained within “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations- Environmental Matters” and “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Credit Facilities Agreement.”

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: At December 31, 2020, the Group had approximately 6,300 employees. Collective bargaining agreements with varying terms and expiration dates cover approximately 5,500 employees. The Group does not expect that renegotiation of the agreements expiring in 2021 will have a material adverse effect on its consolidated results of operations, financial position or cash flow. The Group does not currently expect that any collective bargaining agreements will need to be renegotiated as a result of the Acquisition. We do not currently anticipate material changes in the Group’s employee count after completion of the Acquisition.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, the Group operated 44 manufacturing facilities of which 7 were leased. Certain leases provide renewal or purchase options. The principal manufacturing facilities as at December 31, 2020 are listed below and are grouped by jurisdiction. The Group’s European headquarters are in Baar, Switzerland. The Group maintains a research facility in Wantage, England. The Group’s manufacturing and support facilities are designed according to the requirements of the products to be manufactured. Therefore, the type of construction may vary from plant to plant. Warehouse space is generally provided at each of the manufacturing locations, although the Group also leases outside warehouses. Ongoing productivity improvements and cost reduction efforts in recent years have focused on upgrading and modernizing facilities to reduce costs, improve efficiency and productivity and phase out uncompetitive facilities. The Group has also opened new facilities to meet increases in market demand for its products. These actions reflect the Group’s continued commitment to realign manufacturing facilities to maintain its competitive position in its markets. The Group continually reviews its operations and evaluates strategic opportunities. ----- Utilization of any particular facility varies based upon product demand. While not possible to measure with any degree of certainty or uniformity the production capacity of these facilities, management believes that, if necessary, production can be increased at several existing facilities through the addition of personnel, capital equipment and, in some facilities, square footage available for production. In addition, the Group may from time to time acquire additional facilities or dispose of existing facilities. Excluded from the list below are operating facilities in unconsolidated subsidiaries as well as service or support facilities. The service or support facilities include machine shop operations, plant operations dedicated to printing for cans and closures, coil shearing, coil coating and RD&E operations. Some operating facilities produce more than one product but have been presented below under the product with the largest contribution to sales. The following table summarizes Titan Group’s principal list of manufacturing facilities:

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Facilities** [(1)] France 7 Italy 6 Germany 3 Netherlands 1 Spain 7 U.K. 5 Other European countries[(2)] 10 Rest of the world[(3) ] 5 44 (1) 14 are used for food cans, 17 for food cans/ends, two for food ends, five for closures, three for aerosols and three for promotional products. (2) Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Russia, Poland, Portugal and Turkey. (3) Ghana, Ivory Coast, Madagascar and Morocco.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: The Group carries insurance that it believes to be common in the industry and sufficient to cover the principal risks of damage to its business. The Group maintains insurance policies with respect to certain operating risks, including product liability, damage to property (including buildings, plants, machinery and stock, including as a result of catastrophic events such as fire, flood, storms and earthquakes), industrial accidents, third-party liability, directors’ and officers’ liability, and cyber-crime. The Group undertakes periodic risk reviews to assess whether its insurance is in line with its business risks and whether the developments in insurance policies are reflective of the changes in its business. See "Risk Factors - We may be _subject to losses that might be completely or partially uninsured."_

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: In March 2015, the Bundeskartellamt, or German Federal Cartel Office (“FCO”), conducted unannounced inspections of the premises of several metal packaging manufacturers, including one of the Group’s German subsidiaries. The local court order authorizing the inspection cited FCO suspicions of anti-competitive agreements in the market for the supply of metal packaging products. The Group conducted an internal investigation into the matter and discovered instances of inappropriate conduct by certain employees of German subsidiaries of the Group. The Group cooperated with the FCO and submitted, in September and October 2015, a leniency application with the FCO which disclosed the findings of its internal investigation to date. In April 2018, the FCO discontinued its national investigation and referred the matter to the European Commission (the “Commission”). Following the referral, Commission officials conducted unannounced inspections of the premises of several metal packaging manufacturers, including Group subsidiaries in Germany, France and the United Kingdom. The Commission’s investigation is ongoing and, to date, the Commission has not officially charged the Group or any of its subsidiaries with violations of competition law. The Group is cooperating with the Commission and submitted a leniency application in April 2018. This application may lead to the reduction of possible future penalties. At this stage of the investigation the Group believes that a loss is probable but is unable to predict the ultimate outcome of the Commission’s ----- investigation and is unable to estimate the loss or possible range of losses that could be incurred, and has therefore not recorded a charge in connection with the actions by the Commission. If the Commission finds that the Group or any of its subsidiaries violated competition law, fines levied by the Commission as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement, class action or individual claims and any related costs and damages could be material to the Company’s operating results and cash flows for the periods in which they are resolved or become reasonably estimable. In the Acquisition Agreement, Crown has agreed to indemnify us for certain losses in connection with this investigation. In March 2018, the French Competition Authority started a preliminary investigation regarding possible infringements to French competition law with respect to the switch to bisphenol-A free cans in France which implemented legislation restricting the use of bisphenol-A in all recipients as of 1 January 2015. The French Syndicat National des Fabricants _de Boîtes, a trade association representing food can suppliers in France of which Titan Group is a member, received a_ questionnaire from the French Competition Authority asking for information regarding the trade association’s activities in relation to the development of BPA-NI cans. The French Competition Authority opened formal proceedings regarding possible infringements of competition law in relation to the switch to bisphenol-free cans in France in September 2019. In the context of the formal proceedings, the French Competition Authority sent, in January and February 2020, two questionnaires to Titan Group relating to its activities, internal organization and identification of its different entities and their respective turnovers. In January 2021, Titan Group received a request from the French Competition Authority asking for the permission to declassify documents previously provided by Titan Group in response to the questionnaires received and Titan Group gave the French Competition Authority the permission to do so. The French Competition Authority's investigation is ongoing and, to date, Titan Group has not received any further requests nor questionnaires from the French Competition Authority. At this stage of the investigation, Titan Group is unable to predict the ultimate outcome of the French Competition Authority's investigation and is unable to estimate the loss that it could incur. Should the Board of the French Competition Authority finds that Titan Group or any of its subsidiary violated French competition law, the fine levied by the French Competition Authority (the amount of which is determined on a case-by-case basis depending notably on the seriousness of the infringement as well as its duration, but capped at 10% of the worldwide turnover of the undertaking) could be material to Titan's Group's operating results and cash flows for the periods in which they are resolved or become reasonably estimable, as well as third party damage claims by private enforcement. In the Acquisition Agreement, Crown has agreed to indemnify Titan Group for certain losses in connection with this investigation. In addition to the above legal matter, we are involved in certain other legal proceedings arising in the normal course of our business. We believe none of these additional legal proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, to have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions, results of operations or cash flows. See “Titan Group is subject to an _investigation by the European Commission relating to potential anti-competitive behavior and the outcome of this investigation or future investigations could materially adversely affect Titan Group’s business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Senior Board Members of the Group
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum the below members of the board of directors of Titan Holdings GP Ltd., the general partner of the ultimate parent of the Issuer, have been identified, who will continue or take up their roles following the Completion Date. Crown will, in accordance with the terms of the Shareholders’ Agreement, appoint additional members to this board who are expected to take up their roles following the Completion Date.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Psaros is a Co-Founder and Managing Partner of KPS and a member of its Investment Committee and Management Committee. Mr. Psaros currently serves as Chairman of Autokiniton Global Group, Briggs & Stratton, Lufkin and Speira and serves on the board of directors of AM General, C&D Technologies, DexKo Global, Howden, Hussey Copper, IKG, LifeFitness, Lufkin and TaylorMade Golf, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. In addition, Mr. Psaros previously served on the Board of Directors of 30 former KPS portfolio companies. Mr. Psaros also serves on the Board of Directors of Georgetown University and serves as the Vice Chairman of the Executive Board of Advisors of Georgetown University’s McDonough School of Business and the Board of Advisors of the Georgetown University Center for Financial Markets and Policy. Prior to joining its predecessor and creating KPS in 1997, Mr. Psaros was an investment banker with Bear, Stearns & Co., Inc. He received a B.S.B.A. in Finance from Georgetown University and attended Sophia University in Tokyo, Japan. Mr. Psaros brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Shapiro is a Co-Founder and Managing Partner of KPS and a member of its Investment Committee and Management Committee. Mr. Shapiro currently serves as Chairman of C&D Technologies and TaylorMade Golf and serves on the board of directors of AIS Global, AM General, Autokiniton Global Group, Briggs & Stratton, DexKo Global, Howden, LifeFitness, Lufkin and Speira, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. In addition, Mr. Shapiro previously served on the Board of Directors of 30 former KPS portfolio companies. Prior to joining its predecessor and creating KPS in 1997, Mr. Shapiro was an investment banker with Drexel Burnham Lambert and Dean Witter Reynolds. Mr. Shapiro also serves on the board of the Child Mind Institute and The Doe Fund. He received a B.A. in History from the University of Michigan with High Honors and an MBA with a Specialization in Finance from the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business. Mr. Shapiro brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Ms. Palmer is a Managing Partner of KPS, the Chairperson of its Investment Committee and a member of its Management Committee. Ms. Palmer currently serves as Chairperson of DexKo Global and Howden and serves on the board of directors of AM General, Autokiniton Global Group, Briggs & Stratton, C&D Technologies, LifeFitness, Lufkin, Speira and TaylorMade Golf, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. In addition, Ms. Palmer previously served on the Board of Directors of 30 former KPS portfolio companies. Prior to joining its predecessor and creating KPS in 1997, Ms. Palmer was an investment banker in the Paper and Forest products group with Kidder, Peabody & Co. Ms. Palmer is also the Vice Chairman of The Opportunity Network. Ms. Palmer received a degree in Political Science from Stanford University. Ms. Palmer brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies. -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Bernstein is a Partner of KPS and a member of its Investment Committee and Management Committee. Mr. Bernstein currently serves as Chairman of LifeFitness and serves on the board of directors of AM General, Autokiniton Global Group, Briggs & Stratton, C&D Technologies, DexKo Global, Howden, Lufkin, Speira and TaylorMade Golf, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. In addition, Mr. Bernstein previously served on the Board of Directors of 22 former KPS portfolio companies. Prior to joining KPS in 1999 he was an investment banker in the M&A Group at Schroders plc. Mr. Bernstein received a B.A. in Economics from the University of Michigan with High Honors and an MBA from the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Mr. Bernstein brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Baker is a Partner of KPS. Mr. Baker currently serves on the board of directors of AM General, Briggs & Stratton Lufkin and Speira, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. Prior to joining KPS in 2007, he was an Associate at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP in their Mergers & Acquisitions group. Mr. Baker graduated from the University of Toronto’s Joseph L. Rotman School of Management with an M.B.A and the Faculty of Law with a J.D. Mr. Baker graduated from the University of Western Ontario with a B.S. in computer science and statistical sciences. Mr. Baker brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Mumford is a Partner of KPS. Mr. Mumford currently serves on the board of directors of AM General, Briggs & Stratton and Speira, all of which are portfolio companies of KPS. Prior to joining KPS in 2008, he was an investment banker with UBS Investment Bank in their Global Industrial Group. Mr. Mumford holds a B.A. from Bucknell University in Philosophy and Comparative Humanities. Mr. Mumford brings extensive experience in leadership, finance and business turnarounds to the Board, particularly with respect to manufacturing and industrial companies.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Tomás López has spent his entire career in the canmaking industry. He joined Mivisa in 1980, working closely with the Company’s family ownership until the company’s sale to PAI in 2001. He held senior leadership roles at Mivisa through three successful rounds of private equity ownership (PAI Partners, CVC Capital Partners and Blackstone) serving as CEO of Mivisa from 2005 until it was acquired by Crown in 2014 for €1.2 billion. At Crown, Mr. López served as Senior Vice President of Food Iberia, Africa & South America at Crown until August 2016. Mr. López holds an MBA from University Isabel I of Barcelona and studied law at the University of Murcia.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Tomás López has spent his entire career in the canmaking industry. He joined Mivisa in 1980, working closely with the Company’s family ownership until the company’s sale to PAI in 2001. He held senior leadership roles at Mivisa through three successful rounds of private equity ownership (PAI Partners, CVC Capital Partners and Blackstone) serving as CEO of Mivisa from 2005 until it was acquired by Crown in 2014 for €1.2 billion. Mr. López holds an MBA from University Isabel I of Barcelona and studied law at the University of Murcia.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Laurent Watteaux was appointed Vice President Aerosols & Promotional Packaging of Crown Europe in 2018 after joining in January 2011 as Vice President and General Counsel. Prior to Crown, Mr. Watteaux was in-house legal counsel for the L’Oréal Group and practiced corporate law with Dechert LLP and Weil, Gosthal & Manges. Mr. Watteaux received law degrees from Sorbonnne University (Paris I) in Paris in 1994 and 1995and is a graduate of ESCP Business School Paris in International Law and Business. In 2000, Mr. Watteaux received his Masters of Law degree from New York University, School of Law and completed an Advanced Management Program in 2016 at the IESE Business School in Barcelona. Mr. Watteaux is qualified as a lawyer in New York, England and France.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: John Beardsley was appointed Chief Financial Officer of Crown European Division in January 2014. Mr. Beardsley held a variety of finance roles at Crown across the various business divisions including, Controller in Promotional Packaging, Aerosol Packaging, Finance Director Food Central & Eastern Europe and then Finance Director for the Food sector. Mr. Beardsley commenced his career in junior accounting positions in the UK, working at Elbeo as an Assistant Accountant and thereafter at Robinson Healthcare where he was promoted to Chief Accountant. Mr. Beardsley attended Huddersfield Polytechnic and qualified as a Chartered Certified Accountant in 1997.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Title: Olivier Aubry (Senior Vice President – Sales and Marketing)
Subsubsection Text: Olivier Aubry was appointed Commercial Vice President Food Group Europe in July 2017, after holding a number of commercial and business development roles at Crown. Previously, Mr. Aubry worked as an Export Manager at Monoplast, a Commercial Officer at CarnaudMetalbox and a Customer Manager at Danone before joining Crown. Mr. Aubry holds a degree in engineering from ENSIA (France). -----

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Claudine Schelp was appointed Senior Vice President Sourcing of Crown Europe in April 2018. Prior to Crown, Ms. Schelp was the Chief Procurement Officer of the Rehau Group and the Executive Vice President Sourcing of the Sidel Group. Ms. Schelp previously held various commercial and procurement managerial roles at Autoliv Group, Takata Group and Tetra Laval Group. Ms. Schelp holds a Postgraduate Degree (DESS) in International Business from University of Strasbourg (France), in addition she holds a Master Degree in International Business from University of Caen (France) and graduated with Honors B.A. in European Business Studies from Ulster University (UK).

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Francois Querrioux was appointed Vice President Manufacturing & Quality Food Europe in September 2013, after holder a number of operational and managerial positions across various business divisions of Crown. Mr. Querrioux previously worked as a Manufacturing Engineer and was a Naval Officer in the French Navy. Mr. Querrioux holds an Engineering Degree from ECAM de Lyon (France).

Section Title: BUSINESS
BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Florian Küppers is a Managing Director, Portfolio Operations, of KPS Capital Partners. Prior to joining KPS in 2013, Mr. Küppers was a Manager at Bain & Company. He received a M.S. in Industrial Engineering and Management from the University of Karlsruhe, Germany.

Section Title: BUSINESS
Subsubsection Text: Johannes Timotheüs de Kogel is Vice President, Legal and Compliance of KPS Netherlands Management BV, the Dutch subsidiary of KPS Capital Partners, LP. Prior to joining KPS in 2018, Mr. de Kogel worked for a professional service provider for 10 years. Before that, he was a lawyer for 2 years and admitted to The Hague and Amsterdam bar. Mr. de Kogel graduated from the University of Amsterdam (LL.M, 2006). -----

The directors of the Issuer are Florian Küppers and Johannes Timotheüs De Kogel.
